Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"This is a great little device. I feel the need to defend it from its detractors by echoing what some other reviewers have said about it: don't blame your Kindle for you not having read the product description. It doesn't have a light. You turn the page by touching the screen. You need to be connected to wifi to download a book. If you understand that, you'll enjoy it. Pros: Long battery life. Good amount of storage. Awesome price. It would be kind of nice if there was a ""help"" option on the device itself instead of having to go to the Amazon website, but that's a nonissue once you get the hang of how to navigate everything--the setup tutorial it goes through when you first turn on the device is pretty thorough.If you're not concerned about your Kindle having a light or 3G access, buy this model (the complaints about no page turning buttons are ridiculous and shouldn't even be a factor).",Awesome;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"I have been a long time Amazon customer and very satisfied with my purchases and the service.  But this new version of the basic Kindle is worthless.  The screen is VERY difficult to read unless you are in very bright light.  It is like trying to read a very old newspaper by candle light.  I bought this on the 20% down and 4 equal payments.  I returned it the day after I received it and am now told I cannot purchase the next one up (Paperwhite) on the same program!  Basically, I burned the promotion on the crappy one and now cannot take advantage of it for one that actually works!  I was also told that I could do it if someone else had an account that I could use.  My daughter has an account and when we tried, the promotion does not even show up when she is logged in!  Perhaps because we have the same address?  Either way it sucks..",Don't bother with is version;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"I purchased this Kindle for my father after he broke his Kindle Keyboard. He used his Kindle now and then and after talking with him we decided on this version instead of one more expensive.Very quickly we discovered something rather upsetting which took nearly an hour of online digging to confirm: it has no speakers. My dad started collecting audio books and would listen to them at night. No where on the product page does it state there are no speakers. Had I known this before I would have gone with a PaperWhite, which I myself own.Both of us have struggled with this Kindle's touchscreen. I use touchscreens all day long, including a PaperWhite, with no problems. There are delays between tapping and the reaction at times which prompts you to double tap.Besides these two things the Kindle works as advertised.I would like to see Amazon drop the current shape and material for the slimmer, more rounded design they used before. While I wouldn't count that as a negative it is not a positive either.",Kindle Lost Its Voice;;;;;;

Can't even remove a piece of dust from screen without it flipping to the next page.  Please go back to the  buttons. I miss them and am so unhappy with this Kindle!!
Title;;;;;;: ... Kindles I have purchased this is by far the worst! Why did Amazon try to fix something that ...;;;;;;

Rating: 2.0 out of 5 stars,"I had another kind of Kindle before this one, the one with the keypad at the bottom, the one that allowed pages to be turned by pressing buttons on the side of the Kindle. That one was stolen, and I was very disappointed to learn that that style was no longer available. It was so simple to operate, and had none of the extra sensitivity that this touch-screen model has, which frustrates me a lot. You have to touch it with just the right amount of pressure or it does something you don't want it to do. Everything is different about this Kindle and I don't like any of the difference. It is not an improvement as far as I am concerned, quite the opposite. But, I had no choice, and I don't like that either. I find it difficult to touch the screen just right and in the right place to go to the ""home"" site, and an incorrect touch often brings up a message of some sort that I did not want. I've had it for three weeks and still don't feel comfortable with it. Is this enough of a review? One more comment: I hate it!",and I was very disappointed to learn that that style was no longer available;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"finally i started loving reading.I am from vernacular medium, which made it difficult to read english books for some words not used in regular spoken language.This is perfect,  offline dictionary and low distractions as its not regular tablet which will pop up adds or msgs.the best part is the screen which doesn't make me strain my eyes.I will highly recommend this product.-BG","This is perfect, offline dictionary and low distractions as its not ...";;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"This isn't so much a review of the product, which is fine, so much as a review of Amazon's advertising. I received an email from them telling all the features of their new Kindle Voyage, and boy, did it sound great. The whole email was all about it with pictures of only the Voyage. Then at the bottom of the email is a large button that said, ""Buy the new Kindle for $79."" So, my birthday was coming up so I forwarded the email to my wife. She thought it looked great and ordered it. It shows up around my birthday and we're both wondering why it's thicker than the ad and what happened to the backlight. Go back to the email ad and see that the Kindle she ordered is just called ""Kindle"" but the more expensive models, like the Voyage ($200), have names. To us, they are all Kindles. I wasn't about to send it back, cause it is pretty neat, but I have to read at night with the light on. In closing, Amazon, you get one star for sh***ty advertising.","Great product, deceptive ad";;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"I recently upgraded my Kindle 5th Generation(side buttons/multi-directional keypad) to this current version touchscreen Kindle because Amazon was offering a trade-in on the old kindle plus $20 credit plus towards a new one and a $20 discount off the regular price. After all of that, it only cost me $6.39 which seemed like a perfect time to upgrade! After spending some time with the new Kindle, I came away with mixed feelings with this new Kindle compared to my old 5th Gen Kindle.My initial impressions are its of similar dimension to my old Kindle, but more chunky and feels a bit heavier overall. Holding it in one hand, I notice that the all plastic body is quite slippery and not really grippy at all compared to my old Kindle, which is a bummer. With my old Kindle, I would be able read it in one hand and turn pages as well. With this new Kindle, it's a challenge to hold it in one hand for any extended amount of time to read without it slipping out of my hand. Also, it's a bit uncomfortable to hold because of its chunkiness as well. I wish this new Kindle had a grippy material on the backside like my old Kindle did, which was slim and just much easier for one-handed reading. It seems that Amazon purposely designed this new Kindle to be put in a case as it's just not grippy at all to me and it looks pretty cheap too. I prefer to read without any type of case, but because of this, I may decide to go with a case afterall. The build quality/design also doesnt seem quite up to par because it just comes off as a cheap-looking slab of plastic with not much of a design emphasis. So, I would recommend getting a case to aid in grippiness and to hide the drab look of this Kindle.The touchscreen looks very much like my old Kindle in size and clarity. This Kindle is suppose to have 171 PPI and sharper and bolder text, however compared to my old Kindle, I dont really notice much of a difference. For comparison, I used a 5th gen Kindle from a family member and compared them side by side using the same page from the same book and with the same Bookerly font. I may even say that my old Kindle has a little bolder text compared to the new Kindle, which seems to be on the lighter side despite its claims to sharper and bolder text in its description. So the screen hasnt impressed me much either.The touchscreen responsiveness is fairly good and the page swipes seem quicker than what Im use to on the old Kindle, but not by much. Page swipes are done by actually swiping across the screen or just tapping in the left/right margin or middle of the screen. Tapping at the top brings up the menu with various functions and access to Settings, which is little more convenient than my old Kindle. One thing Ive noticed is that the text on-screen doesnt actually utilize the whole screen, depending on the book. The top margin starts lower than my old Kindle because of this tap to access menu function. Thats about an inch of wasted space in the top margin on every page which is disappointing to say the least, especially on a 6 screen. This doesnt happen with every book for some reason, so this may be some glitch with a particular book. On my 5th Gen Kindle, this never happened at all, but something to note on this newer Kindle as it may be indicate buggy issues with the software.The storage is 4GB for even a 1000 more books, which is double my 5th Gen Kindle, but its not really important to me as I keep most of my books in the cloud and only keep what Im currently reading and some other ebooks I may read down the road on the Kindle. Once Im done, I usually keep any purchased  ebooks but not obviously any borrowed ebooks from the library. I will never have a need to keep my entire library of ebooks on the kindle at one time unless there some type of apocalypse happens that lasts years and years. If that happens, the kindle would probably be fried anyway;")Battery life seems to be similar to my old kindle as Ive not had to charge it yet as of this review. It came shipped with about 60-70% battery life. Hopefully
Review: it will last as long as my old Kindle
Title;;;;;;: time will tell.I do like some of the new features like being able to browse through page by page or chapter by chapter without losing your place in the book. This is probably the best new feature of the Kindle that I didnt have on my old version. The Goodreads collaboration

Rating: 1.0 out of 5 stars,"In a comparison with my 4th generation basic kindle (who has now passed on after ~3 years), this product is inferior in nearly every way.It feels and looks a lot more clunky;" you're gaining a noticeable amount of weight and thickness in exchange for a touchscreen feature. The purpose of purchasing a basic kindle for me at least is to read
Review: plain and simple. I only have two requirements for the kindle: 1) small and lightweight
Title;;;;;;: and 2) easy page flipping. Any advantage gained by touchscreen is far outweighed by the loss of the page buttons.I experimented with a number of hand positions

Rating: 3.0 out of 5 stars,"First off, I would like to share that I owned the kindle keyboard, the kindle fire hd and now I have the kindle hd 6, so I have had experience with a few different models. I purchased this model, because I wanted a reader I could take outdoors when my children were playing that wouldn't distract me from reading like my kindle fires end up doing.This model is very basic. It's good over all. The touchscreen works very well and it does what it's supposed to do, but I wasn't happy with the darkness of the screen. I felt like I needed a little more contrast between the background and the actual font.I ordered the paperwhite to see if the difference would justify the extra expense. For me, it definitely does. The background light makes a huge difference. I'm sending this one back and keeping the paperwhite.All in all, it's a great reader for the price, has all the basics. Just not the reader for me though.","Good, but basic...";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I bought this as a ""beach kindle"" because I'm not comfortable taking my Voyage to the beach (ironically enough). This Kindle does everything that I could have expected it to do and does it well, as I've come to expect from Amazon. I'm very pleased with my purchase.","... bought this as a ""beach kindle"" because I'm not comfortable taking my Voyage to the beach (ironically enough)";;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"Overall, I am enjoying this a lot.  One thing I don't like however is that the screen is extremely sensitive and even the tiniest of touches will advance the page and lose my place.  Also, the part of the screen that you press to go to the previous pages really only works reliably once.  If you want to go back two pages at a time you're almost screwed.  It has been hard for me to figure out how to do that as the device wants to interpret the second touch as a ""go forward"" command and you wind up going in circles.In the plus column, I am VERY happy that amazon has continued the e-ink format.  I read ten times as much when I don't have glare giving me a migraine.",One thing I don't like however is that the screen is extremely sensitive and ...;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I purchased this to supplement a 1st generation iPad mini. It's exactly what I expected to be: a simple device to read e-books on so I don't stare at an LCD screen all day, especially in situations where tablets get too much glare. The build quality though does feel a bit on the cheap side coming from a higher end tablet, but for $79 it's fine.Amazon's integration with Overdrive is great too for checking out library books. The ads on the lock screen really aren't too bothersome at all.",What I expected;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"I previous had the Kindle Keyboard and was devastated when after 5 years of use the screen had some major issues that couldn't be fixed. Please note I travel constantly and even though I always kept it in a case it definitely had some tough love but worked great up until the end.The new kindle has the same great screen without glare.  It's easy to navigate to order books, use the dictionary while reading, highlight quotes in books and set up wifi(however it was easier to turn it on and off on the Kindle Keyboard interface).The one major downside to the new Kindle is the touchscreen sensitivity.  I frequently read in bed and if my blanket grazes the screen it changes pages, font size or resets me to the beginning of the my book.  There's no adjustability that I'm aware of in the settings and every night when I read I miss the buttons to turn the pages.",Screen Is Way Too Sensitive;;;;;;

Review: my kindle is great...but when reading sometimes the book page flips 2 pages at a time when the screen get touched...please fix this bug...overall i'm very satisfied with my kindle and i think I'm not going to read books with my iPad anymore..

Rating: 3.0 out of 5 stars,"It pains me to say that I only have a single major complaint.  Otherwise this feels like a 5-star product.The grey screen is too dark.  It is too dark in dim light, and it is too dark in bright light.Here, at my computer, in my ""normal lighting situation"", the room is dim.  I'm using the light from the lowest (13W) settings of an 3-way efficiency bulb in a shaded lamp, and have the glow of two monitors.  This is just enough light for most things, from balancing my checkbook, to looking up which special characters I used in a particular password, to, yes, casual reading.  This is enough light to read white paper by.  Now, grey paper, when newspaper or IRS tax booklets may indeed need more light, which is fine, because I have two more clicks on my lamp.  So, I have suffered mildly trying to use my kindle in this dim situation.I had thought, fine, I'll just have to use this in bright light.  Alas, that doesn't work well either.  Being in a bright room naturally constricts my pupils so that I need more light.  The contrast on the kindle is thus effectively worse.  Looking around the room, everything is bright and cheery, until you look at this device and I wonder what this murky grey thing is doing here.  I have to concentrate to read it in bright light too.  In bright situations, if my eyes are adjusted to reading on this, then I actually feel the need to turn down the lights in my environment.To repeat myself in summary, the grey kindle screen is too dark in dim light.  It's too dark in bright light.  Great product otherwise.",The grey screen is too dark.;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I received the Amazon Kindle on the release date of October 2.  Thus far I have been very happy with it.  I have the Kindle Fire and the Kindle Fire HD and have been pleased with them.  However, I wanted something that was more exclusively an e-reader with the glare-free screen that I could take with me on the go for reading.  I have my smartphone with me when I am out or at work so bringing a Kindle Fire with me seemed redundant.  I also rationalized my purchase of yet another Kindle by the fact that when I read on my other Kindles, I am easily distracted by the other apps and end up spending too much time with those rather than enjoying reading.I like the screen and the size.  I find it much easier to read than my other Kindles, even with their matte screen protectors.  The touchscreen is a nice addition with this version.  I am used to this with my other Kindles so it is an easy transition.I also like that you can organize your books.  That is something that I had longed for with my other Kindles.  I think it will be nice to file away the books that I have read and the books to be read.  I can think of all kinds of possibilities for this feature.  I had been considering the previous generation, which I think was $69 as opposed to $79 and I am glad that I waited.I may update when I have had the product longer.",Kindle 7th Generation with Special Offers;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I bought this Kindle because I love to read and my First Generation Kindle died. It was easy to upload my unread books, load some more and head to the beach. I don't mind the ads because they aren't too obtrusive and I tend to ignore them. I didn't see the need to pay extra to exclude ads.  This Kindle is compact and fits in a small purse.I also have an iPad but it is impossible to read outside and it doesn't fit in a small purse. In the picture below, the Kindle is upright so it can be seen but I can lay it down and zip the purse.",a No Frills E-Reader;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"I had the kindle a generation before this one which I loved, but it broke one day after a friend sat on it... I thought that the new generation could only be better, but I was wrong. The last generation was thinner and lighter. Though this generation is still pretty light, its heavy enough for me to feel that itd slip when only holding it with one hand. (Granted I have small hands.) Also, the black framing looks thicker and the screen looks smaller. I feel that the touchscreen is unnecessary for a simple ereader, especially if you use it mainly for reading and not for taking notes, which is what I do. I loved the buttons on the side used to change pages in the previous version, but they have been changed to swiping. The layout of the home page, etc is more cluttered now if I'm remembering my old kindle correctly. It might be weird that I'm complaining about it having more functions, but I feel that a kindle ereader should stay simple and do its job: be as portable as possible, be efficient to use, and show me my books. Anything else is superfluous and you might as well buy a tablet.",More is not always better;;;;;;
5.0 out of 5 stars,"Perfect for what I got it for...reading outside. Hello, beach, here I come!",Five Stars;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"This is my second Kindle, an upgrade from a 2nd generation keyboard model. It still worked, but the Prime Day deal was irresistible. I am so glad I took the plunge. The new Kindle is lighter and smaller, but has a larger reading area. Handling it is similar to a paperback, once its in a case. Open it, and you see the last thing you saw when you closed it. How easy is that? I find the text to be as crisp as traditional print, and the contrast with the background less fatiguing on the eyes than my previous Kindle. I tend to be a binge reader, so that makes a big difference, as does the lack of a backlight. The frame is far less distracting as there are no buttons or letters to draw the eye away from what you are reading. Despite being in black and white, the pictures in my cookbooks are rendered in enough detail to be appealing.  It's like looking at the pictures in a mass-market paperback. It's no coffee-table display, but it gives the general idea.The user interface is invisible, yet always close at hand. One tap and I can navigate, check references or definitions, see where I am in the book and how much is left, or simply check the time, without leaving the page or picking up another device. The gestures are intuitive, if you're accustomed to a smartphone or tablet, so there's no learning curve. It comes already linked to your Amazon account, so upgrading is mostly done when you get it. It took about ten minutes to open the box, put it in the new case, set up the wi-fi, and download my collections and books from the Cloud. I appreciate not having to re-organize all my books back into their groups. Because it doesn't automatically download every book I've ever purchased, I don't have to waste space on the device on the few duds I've happened across. (Of course, if I'm desperate and near wi-fi, I can get them from the Cloud;" nothing is gone forever) Realistically
Review: I'm unlikely to ever run out of space
Title;;;;;;: even if I kept everything on the device. 4G holds a lot of text.Reading other reviews

Review: Really cheap product. Slow and difficult to use. You have to tap it so many times before the screen registers and changes page or goes to the library. Wish I would have just stuck to the kindle app instead of wasting money on this. Hate it.

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"I've been an avid reader from the moment I first learned to read. This means over the years I have collected tons of books. Sure I've downsize plenty of times, gave books away to friends or donations but still somehow before I knew it I once again has too many books and no place to store new ones. It was a vicious cycle. So I as much as I was against them, I decided to get an e-reader.I originally had a nook color and that was my first introduction into e-readers. It was great for graphic novels and comics but not so much for actual novels. My eyes would hurt and strain from the back light and text. I also hated reading outside on a bright sunny day since all I would experience was glare. While for the most part I was happy with it (I could play games on it!) I was also extremely unhappy. Eventually my nook suffered extreme water damage, so I was then in the market for a new e-reader. I tried to save myself some money by reading on my iPad but I encountered the same problems as I did with the nook. Painful, strained eyes from the back light when reading for prolonged times and of course the dreaded sunny day glare (which those of us with iPads know that glare pretty much renders them useless since you cannot see a thing), plus my iPad is a bulky 2nd generation and because of the weight it gets pretty tiring holding that thing for a lengthy time reading. Because of my inability to comfortably read, I started buying physical books again... and once again ran out of room to store them.I started doing my research on some basic e-readers (such as the Kindle, Kindle Paperwhite and the Nook Glowlight). I didn't want one of the tablet e-readers since I already had an iPad, so why do I need all the bells and whistles? So, I compared each of the ereaders I was interested in and the Nook Glowlight was originally winning the race, since I had a whole library of ebooks purchased from Barnes and Noble from my previous device and the price was excellent. 100 bucks for basically the BN version of the Kindle Paperwhite. It was cheaper than buying the Paperwhite from Amazon... but then prime day happened.A basic Kindle (with special offers) for 50 bucks? SOLD!I had heard of the pricing when sales had leaked a few days before prime day and I told a few people I knew I was buying a Kindle. My husband pointed out a few things such as ""There is no backlight"" - Well the backlight was my main issue with my previous e-reader and my iPad so no backlight? No problem! ""What about your previous Barnes and Noble library?"" - I already read them all, I'll buy new books. Again, No problem! ""What if you want to read in the dark?"" - I turn on a light! Problem solved! and last but not least ""Don't you think the special offers will get annoying?"" - Nope, in fact something might catch my eye and it will serve more like a recommendation on what to read next. I had it all figured out. I was buying a Kindle.The day my Kindle came, I was so excited that I immediately set it up. I took advantage of a trial month of Kindle Unlimited so I started reading right away. I am beyond thrilled I made this purchase. The Kindle so far has lived up to my every expectation (granted I have only had the device for 5 days). I have no issues with my eyes hurting or straining while reading. I have been able to take advantage of a breezy summer day by reading in my backyard without an issue of glare from the sun. The photo I've included with my review is the clearness of the screen outside on a sunny day. I was so impressed with the lack of glare, I immediately took a picture with intentions of adding it to this review. The weight of the Kindle is practically nothing, so it doesn't become annoying holding it for a prolonged reading session. I'm also very impressed with the battery life. I've been reading daily for about an hour or so each day and I haven't needed to charge my Kindle yet (except for the initial charging when it arrived). I also love the ability to use amazon household to share libraries. My husband uses the Kindle app on his tablet so I am able to read what he reads on my kindle.I am extremely happy to have bought a Kindle which originally I would have never done so if it hadn't gone on sale during prime day. But I will admit that would have been so foolish because even at 79 dollars The Kindle (with special offers) is worth every penny.",One of the best purchases I have ever made.;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I purchased the new (Oct 2014) basic Kindle. I just wanted a simple e-reader so that I can have all my books with me to read where ever I am.  The resolution doesn't seem as crisp and bright as my previous Kindle Touch but it gets the job done.  I notice that everything is now stored on the cloud and you have to transfer the books over to the device.  I transferred all my collections over to the device but in doing so the books remained in the cloud.  I had to take the added step to add the books within the collections to the device;" making this Kindle for me rather clunky to use.  Finally
Review: at first this new Kindle felt awkward and too chunky in my hands but it fits perfectly in my old Kindle Touch case and now I don't mind it.I have owned two Kindle Touches before this Kindle.  Both of them just stopped working one before the warranty ended and the second just after the warranty ended.  I have never dropped my Kindles nor do I abuse them
Title;;;;;;: so I decided this time to buy the basic Kindle on sale (thank you Black Friday) and when it dies then at least I will feel as if I've gotten my monies worth.I am disappointed that this Kindle doesn't have speakers and no longer offers the text-to-speech (TTS) feature. I was going to return it to purchase the Paperwhite but found it no longer offers the feature either.  I was so happy with all the features of my Kindle Touch.  It was such a pleasure to discover all that it did.  I could understand if Amazon decided to make a base model that didn't have all the goodies but to redesign Kindle models to take features away from us
column4: so that we have to purchase the highest priced Kindle models for the TTS feature
column5: just seems like Amazon is adding value to some of its customers by taking from the others.""
column6: Does What it is Supposed to but No Text-to-Speech Feature...";;;;;

Review: Got it today as promised.  Was not sure if I would like the touch screen Kindle.  I've had Kindle with a keyboard since 6-7 years.  The initial impression is it is really good.  Found it easy to read and the controls are easy to use. The books got synced up in minutes once I logged in. Now to get a cover for it.

Rating: 1.0 out of 5 stars,"I must hold the Kindle in my left hand.  I had a Kindle Keyboard which I could hold and turn the pages with my one hand.  I broke the screen and had to buy a new Kindle and ended up with the new touchscreen Kindle.  It is very difficult to hold and turn the pages with just the left hand.  Sometimes it goes to the next page, sometimes back a page, sometimes it opens the dictionary, and sometimes it highlights the text.  It is driving me crazy.  I would not recommend it to anyone who is left handed.  I wish I had bought an old Kindle Keyboard on Ebay.",I would not recommend it to anyone who is left handed;;;;;;

2.0 out of 5 stars,"I have been very disappointed with my new Kindle 6"" Glare-Free e reader.  I loved my old one and sorry it died.... There are many times when it doesn't take actions as needed.  i.e., page turning, scrolling up or down.  It will simply do nothing or, to my frustration, if your finger is near the page it will jump and sometimes it takes several minutes to find where you were.  It seems to me that in this case, progress has taken a big step backwards in this new edition.  I'm not very happy and would not recommend it.  You need to improve this reader or remove it....Bobbie",THIS READER NEEDS IMPROVEMENT;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"I have had a Kindle Touch with one of those lighted leather covers for years. I tend to lose things on airplanes so I like to keep a spare.  I was very excited to see that Amazon started making the Touch again because I'm using a refurbished one now.This is shorter and wider than the old Kindle Touch.  It has no Home button and it has no contacts at the back to power a light.  Worst of all, it looks and feels cheap.  The screen seems to be the same but the body is a cheap, black plastic.I didn't bother setting it up so I don't know how well it actually works.  I am still trying to decide whether or not to send it back.",This is a big disappointment - Please bring back the old Kindle Touch;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I like the kindle. I think for the price it's unbeatable in quality. I used it everyday. And enjoyed it thoroughly.However if you can afford the paperwhite, it's worth the premium. I took mine back and purchased the paperwhite and I can say, I won't be going back. The build quality and overall usefulness of the paperwhite is well worth the $40.However if your budget does not allow it. This kindle is still a favorite of mine. Just full light is needed and it does scratch easily.","Great product, prefer paperwhite.";;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"Very nice book reader. Also comes with promotional Unlimited Reading ability to get any book from the list for a month.What is a bit annoying in the amazon interface is that if you click buy, even mistakenly, then the purchase is made without any explicit confirmation or password",Very nice book reader;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"I highly recommend never buying one of these. I got this for Christmas and about a year and 4 month later I go an error message that read: Kindle Needs Repair. I called Amazon and they told me the device was dead and there was nothing they can do. They offered me a ""discount"" for a refurbished one which was actually more than if I just ordered a new on from their website. I babied this product. I had it in a hard case and only charged when the battery was very low. The book stayed on my night stand 24/7, so it was never abused out in the world.  I only read about 10 books on the device. I won't ever be buying one of these again since Amazon won't back thier product for more than a year.",Poorly built product that Amazon doesn't back with a good warranty!;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I have the first gen fire but this my first e ink kindle I've owned. I love reading, and this kindle is perfect. It's so light! Much easier to read on this than a book. It's not backlit, but who cares? Neither are my physical books. The software is neat. I really like the built in dictionary and flash cards. And the battery lasts forever. I hardly use my fire anymore, and when I do it's not for reading. This kindle is perfect :)",First time kindle buyer;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"This is my first Kindle, but I've been using the Kindle app on my Samsung Galaxy Note II for quite some time. Initially, I held out on buying any kind of e-reader. I enjoy the feel of a paperback in my hands. However, I am in many Lit classes and the cost of books has been piling up. When this Kindle went on sale for $59, I decided I could finally justify buying this ""non-essential"" item. I only got it yesterday, but I am so glad that I have it now. The screen is crisp and clear. I prefer it much more than reading on the Kindle app, probably because it is not back lit, so it is easy on the eyes. The battery seems to last forever. I stayed up hours reading last night. If I had been on my phone, I would've needed to plug it into the charger long before I wanted to stop reading. Though page turns are smoother on the app, turning pages on my Kindle doesn't jar me out of my reading experience at all. Some people complain about a lack of buttons for page turning, but I don't see the need for them since this Kindle is touchscreen. I'm already used to tapping to turn pages on the app, so, in this, the two are exactly the same. Additionally, I love the size. It's bigger than my phone, but not cumbersome, so it's easy to read lying in bed (with a bedside lamp on, of course). The only thing remotely negative that I can say isn't even about the Kindle itself; it's about the need to separately purchase a power adapter. Don't waste your money on the official Kindle adapter. I purchased a universal USB power adapter for $6 that works just as well; there's no need to spend $20 on it. If you have a cell phone charger that uses an adapter
Review: you don't really even need to buy one at all;" I only did for convenience sake. All in all
Title;;;;;;: I am extremely happy with my purchase.""
column4: I enjoy the feel of a paperback in my hands";;;

Rating: 4.0 out of 5 stars,"Although I love Kindles in general, I gave this 4 stars mainly in comparison to the other versions available. I actually purchased this Kindle for my son and the Paperwhite for myself and I find myself now wishing that I had just purchased two Paperwhites.  The standard kindle without advertisements is about $99 and the kindle Paperwhite with advertisements was $119, but that extra $20 gets you a much improved screen and a reading light that really comes in handy.  The reading light is especially useful for me, because I read to my son when he goes to bed. My advice is to just buy the Paperwhite itself, and not worry about the case or charging adapter, because you could buy similar items of the same quality from other makers for much cheaper than the $50 and $20 respectively.  With regards to whether or not to get one without the advertisements (you have to pay extra to get one that is advertisement-free) I normally hate advertisements but these ones are really unobtrusive because they only occur when the kindle isn't being actively used.  I dont own a Kindle Voyage, but I used a friends Voyage and I didnt see anything that really justified the extra price.  The screens look basically the same, and the only major difference is the sensors that automatically adjust the reading light, which might be important for some people but probably not so much for most users.",Although I love Kindles in general;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"This Kindle is a replacement for my Kindle Keyboard, which bit the dust a couple of weeks ago.  I loved my previous Kindle model.  I loathe the new one.  With a burning hatred I find hard to contain.  The touchscreen is the MOST annoying thing ever.  However, if you've never used a non-touchscreen Kindle, you may have a different opinion.With my previous Kindle, I could hold the device anywhere and not lose my place in the book. If it slipped in my hands, grabbing it anywhere was OK.  With this one, ANY light touch to the screen changes something.  My ponytail accidentally touched it and some stupid window to change text size popped up.  I've lost count of the number of times it has jumped ahead several pages when I only tapped the screen once.The reason I purchased a replacement Kindle instead of using my iPad is because it's smaller, lighter and better on the battery.  But this Kindle sucks.  I miss the buttons to change the page, to go ""Home"" or ""Back"" or turn Wi-Fi on/off.  With my previous Kindle, I could hold it in my left hand while I ate lunch.  My right hand could hold a fork while my left hand could change the page.  Not with this one.  You have to tap the right side of the screen to jump ahead.  My thumb isn't 8"" long so it doesn't reach the right side.So I will take apart my old Kindle to try to fix it because I'm this close to playing Frisbee with the new one.  If that fails, well, I don't know what I'll do but I'll still hate the new Kindle.  This will never change.  But I miss the buttons.  I'm tired of jumping through hoops for functionality that was once available with one key.  There's too much tapping for me.","As a replacement for my Kindle Keyboard, this one sucks";;;;;;

Review: I Not sure what went wrong but it sure did... I returning this for Full Refund!  It took me Several days to Load ALL my ebooks  & place them into Collections just for them to VANISH within a week!  Tried again they VANISHED again...  I gave up!AMAZON BRING BACK THE K3s!!!  :(  I Miss them!

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"I have debated getting a Kindle for a long time, but was never sure I wanted to give up on holding a real book and turning real pages. Well, I finally decided to try the basic Kindle, and I am pleasantly surprised how much I enjoy reading on this. I definitely read more now that I have the Kindle. It's comfortable to hold, there is zero eye strain, and overall usability is excellent. Having so many cheap or free books available through Kindle deals has already increased my Kindle library substantially. I bought a Fintie Folio Case and they are a great fit.Screen: excellent, clear, no eye strain, easy to readTouch: excellent, intuitive, responsive, turning pages happens subconsciously nowCasing: good, plastic, but not uncomfortable, maybe would have preferred a little matte finish for gripSpeed: responsive, no lag, page turns do not noticeably flash like the Kindle keyboard I tried out from a friend, which was distractingAs a former Kindle skeptic, I would recommend this to anyone who isn't sure they want to give up on real paper. I am very happy with my purchase.","I read more now, the Kindle is very enjoyable";;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"This Kindle reader is exactly as described. We have used our Kindle Fire for our e-books, but it was difficult or impossible to read in bright sunlight. With the  new Kindle Reader 6"", bright light is no problem, even on the beach. That said, it does not have a back light, so it can not be read without light or in low light conditions. Think of a hard copy of a book. This unit weighs just 6.5 ounces, outside measures  6.5"" X 4.625"". Screen is 4.75 X 3.5"" This Kindle was easy to start-up, and a users manual was included in the unit. Books that I had on the Kindle Fire, transferred to the Kindle Reader.  This just arrived yesterday, so I have not really explored all the features, so I can not comment on those. The only reason for the 4 star was the lack of backlighting, but your books can be read in bright sunlight. The attached photo was taken this morning in direct sunlight.  For the price, this was a true bargain.",Great for reading in bright light.;;;;;;

Review: Love the smaller design had the previous keyboard kindle. Chose the touch because I like the long battery life of my previous one. This one would have got 5 stars if 1st it had the nice screen savers like my previous one and 2nd if it had text to speech like the kindle keyboard. I love reading on a Kindle they are awesome devices . I cried when I lost my kindle keyboard had it been my ipad I would not have been that upset.
Title;;;;;;: Kindles are great for those who love to read !;;;;;;

Rating: 3.0 out of 5 stars,"Works good, I do prefer the original Kindle using buttons to turn pages however.",I like buttons;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"On Cyber Monday I bought this Kindle and I'm very happy to report how pleased I am with this easy to read E-Reader. That very day of delivery I read a Nicholas Sparks book that I purchased. Love having a book at the touch of my fingers. Easy to turn pages, just a swipe with your thumb. The Kindle is so lightweight. Easy to use, easy and quick to download a book. It came charged also , which made it easy to immediately begin using. I love all the handy features that it provides. There is not a BACKLIGHT, you won't need it. It has a glare-free, easy on the eyes screen. Which is great for me. Reading on a computer is very hard on my eyes because of a backlight. It can cause my eyes to become bothersome and dry. A BACKLIGHT is hard on your eyes and can also keep you from sleeping peacefully. Should you purchase this e-reader I believe you will also be very happy and find what a well made device it is. What a cyber Monday deal! Wow!",GREAT CYBER MONDAY BUY;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"I like that this kindle has a touch screen and everything except for one annoying thing works as it should. Sometimes without warning, the text will change to a smaller or larger font without me touching the screen at all, and I have to change it back. Irritating bug.",annoying bug;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"It's really nice to read on and very easy to use. I gave it 5 stars because it works exactly as advertised, but I regret not getting the one with the backlight. I didn't think I would use the light that much, so I figured I would save myself the money. After using it and enjoying it, I realized how much a light would help. I have since then bought an external light for it, but the all in one would have been a better choice. If you are debating on this one or the one with the light. I would go for the backlight version.",Get the backlight Version;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"I ordered the older version that has buttons and got the newer version with touch screen. That may seem like a bonus to you but not to me. Plus I paid for postage when I bought it and then had to pay postage to pick it up at the post office. That didn't make me a happy camper. The reason I wanted the older generation with the buttons was because of a medical situation that just makes buttons easier, it seems they are phased out and even though the device that was pictured had the needed buttons and was referred to as ""previous generation"" I still got the newer model. All of the new Kindles are touch screen now which means I probably wont ever buy another one. Good job Amazon.",That may seem like a bonus to you but not to me;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"The screen has touch aspects similar to those of the Fires, which are nice. However, the screen and the font are not as clear as my old kindle keyboard, and it therefore hurts my eyes. Overall, I was very disappointed in it.  I nearly returned it, but kept it in case my keyboard died.",Rather disappointed in its screen and fonts; the old kindle keyboard is easier on the eyes.;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I have used my 3rd generation Kindle keyboard since it was launched and I recently bought this one for my brother. I still use my Kindle keyboard, but after trying this one, the old girl is now feeling a little slow and little washed-out and I'm thinking of upgrading to the paperwhite soon. I don't imagine many of you are first-time Kindle users, and many may be wondering if the latest Kindles are worth the upgrade. I wondered the same myself and I'm just here to tell you that after using it, I'm now convinced that the better refresh-rate, contrast, blacker blacks and whiter whites and lighter weight are worth an upgrade.Kindle units in general have changed my life for the better and I have totally forgiven Amazon for losing $9k on their stock back when I was younger. Thank you Amazon.",Worth an upgrade but the paperwhite may be better.;;;;;;

2.0 out of 5 stars,"It really was a disappointment compared with my older Kindle Touch.  Using the touchscreen to get to the menu is tricky and much of the time you get to a dictionary entry instead of the menu.  The menu button on the touch is much more convenient.  It also seems much lighter and flimsier in your hand.  The Touch seems to be much more solid and sturdy.Also, there did not seem to be an option for a leather case and the new synthetic case feels cheaply made.",It really was a disappointment compared with my older Kindle Touch;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"I wish I could combine the old Kindle with this touch Kindle. Touch is good for taking notes, but a hassle because the pages get turned from merely holding the Kindle. Pretty annoying. I wish you could turn the touch feature on and off, just like you turn wireless on and off. I already gave my mother my old Kindle, and she likes it, so I'll put up with this one for now. No matter what, it's a Kindle, so you can carry one device and have hundreds of books at your fingertips, and the database for free Kindle books on Amazon is amazing. More than you could ever read in a lifetime.","It's a Kindle, I think you'll like it.";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I've owned 2 Nook e-readers over the past 5 years or so. In that amount of time, I've bought close to 200 e-books. A few months ago I started comparing the price of Kindle e-books with Nook e-books and I've found that Kindle is usually $2 to $5 cheaper than Nook and at worst, the same price. For the books I read, I have yet to see a Nook e-book cheaper than Kindle.As a result, I felt like I was just wasting money buying e-books from Nook so on cyber Monday, I bought the cheaper Kindle for $49. I'm assuming I'll make up for the price of the Kindle within 3 or 4 months a little at a time every time I purchase Kindle e-books.A little bit of a learning curve was involved with this. The Nook was touch screen and this is touch screen. Little differences in functionality but easy enough to learn. I will only be using this Kindle to read books so didn't want or need any of the Kindles that have more bells & whistles. If I need to read in bed at night or at low light, I have the Kindle app on my smart phone.The main reason I bought this Kindle was because the Kindle e-books are cheaper but now that I have it, I'm very pleased with it.",Replacing a Nook;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"I bought the older version of this to give my daughter a gift. After 1.5 year, the half of screen was out without any reason. She didn't drop nor push the screen. Just lower part of screen is dead and upper part is working well. I asked customer service to repair it but surprisingly there is no repair option. Instead, Gowtham who answered my request, offered me replacement option only to $125-$200 version of kindle. If Amazon agrees to offer replacement for the defect of the product, Amazon has to offer the similar product that a customer bought, not trying to sell more expensive product. I ended up the chatting with Gowtham. Even though he/she was polite he couldn't help me as the policy was wrong.",No replacement option for low-end version of kindle;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I've owned about 3 Kindles, and I think this is probably my favorite.  It is simple to use and faster than the kindle keyboard or the fire.  I really just wanted something to be able to read ebooks on, and this Kindle was perfect for that.  I love the touch screen and how responsive it is.  The battery life is amazing as well.  It truly is a glare-free screen, so I can read anywhere.  I think the only thing I miss on this Kindle is a headphone port for audiobooks or text to speech, but because books can sync across devices, for the times that I want to listen to a book I just use my phone instead of the Kindle. This is a really lightweight device that isn't super fragile, so it is easy to take it places (like waiting rooms) and not worry about it getting broken in my bag on the way there.  It doesn't require as much protective gear as a tablet either, which makes it more cost effective in supplies and power consumption.",and I think this is probably my favorite. It is simple to use and faster than ...;;;;;;

Review: This device is amazing. For 59 dollars it was 1000 percent worth the upgrade for me from the 3rd gen Kindle. This device has touchscreen which makes it a million times easier to flip pages. The processor is fast there is barely any time before it loads the next page. This device is worth it at 100 bucks but in March 2015 you can get it from 59$ instead of 79$ if your iffy about buying this device just do it. I was too but I am happy with my purchase.

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"I received my Kindle 6"" as a gift and didn't know much about them or if I would even find much use for it. Boy, has this device changed my life! I detest reading. I read only if a job or problem requires it. I never made time for reading prior to owning my Kindle.First of all, when I powered on my Kindle, it welcomed me, personally, and thanked me for my purchase. Somehow it ties to the account it was purchased with unless otherwise specified. Cool. Creepy in some ways;" but cool. Skeptical
Review: I continued to operate the device and was guided to download a couple free books with my Prime membership.I purchased a couple titles on the off chance that I had some time where my Internet was out or I was stranded somewhere with no cell phone service so I still had something to do. A week after owning my Kindle we had a Tornado watch
Title;;;;;;: in which my family gathers in a safe spot until the watch downgrades to a warning. All my mobile devices were occupied by other family members waiting patiently for the storm to pass
column4: so I picked up my Kindle and began to explore.I began reading and immediately paid attention to the line numbers
column5: page numbers
column6: percent completed
column7: and estimated time remaining. Cool! I activated WordWise
column8: which identifies key words
column9: sentences
column10: characters and events and gives me a brief summary. When I go a few days without reading
column11: WordWise can quickly remind me where I'm at in the story. Neat! Kindle also never loses my place whether reading on Kindle
column12: my iPhone
column13: iPad
column14: or desktop PC. That's convenient! Lastly
column15: I can store hundreds of books on my Kindle
column16: and infinitely more in the cloud
column17: so there's no bulk besides the device itself. No clutter!I've now added several more books to my Amazon wishlist and will wait for them to go on sale
column18: but my reading habits have changed and its all thanks to Kindle! Kindle makes reading enjoyable in an increasingly digital world.""
column19: Kindle Makes Reading Enjoyable In An Increasingly Digital World";;;;;

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"I have now had this item for well over a year and after having experimented with several generations of kindles including the 1st generation kindle released by Amazon,  I have to say that this remains my favorite item and the newer generations have not been tempting at all.  The main difference is that this kindle reads just like any paperback or hardback book that you might purchase at a store for pleasure, study, or work.  There is absolutely not glare so you can read your media in any circumstance that you might have to endure.  It is also easy to use and the pages turn with a flick of a finger.  The only thing I wish that was different on this item is the plastic shell as it is quite easy to scratch.  I do recommend purchasing a protection case for any of your Kindle Products",After Having Owned Several Generations of Kindle This Particular One Remains My Favorite;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"This thing is a joke. Its darker than an actual paper book. Even in full sunlight, or with a reading light it hurt my eyes. Mine also had a weird glitch where anytime you touched the screen to turn a page etc, a circular halo flickered across as did thewords. Don't waste your time or money on this, spend the extra $40 and get the paperwhite.","Dont waste your time, buy the paperwhite instead!";;;;;;

2.0 out of 5 stars,"I returned this item because of a single major flaw: pdf rendering. It's great for everything else.I use lots of PDF books, and a lot of them are scanned books, with pages in the JBIG2 compression algorithm. This is the best B&W image compression routine ever invented. You can have a 300dpi book, 6x9"" pages, 400 pages, all in maybe a 7MB file size. It's awesome.But kindle can't properly render JBIG2 compressed PDFs. It's like someone went through the book and randomly erased characters. Like to the tune of half a dozen characters from every page, just gone. ""For e ample, im gine h w hard it wo ld be to re d somethi g with lots of mi sing chara ters!""I've used these same PDFs with dozens of other devices and software packages, and they always show perfectly. Except on kindle. Seems to be a universal problem with kindle PDF rendering engine, because I've seen the same thing in multiple kindle e-ink devices and even on a friend's kindle fire.I know this is a very specialized problem, and probably won't affect a lot of people at all. But if you need good PDF support...probably ought to look elsewhere.",It's great for everything else;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I love carrying this lightweight kindle and reading books.  I have a Kindle Fire, but it is so much heavier.  That is the reason that I ordered this.  I have so  many books in it to read ;" and yet
Review: it is lighter than carrying a paperback book.""
Title;;;;;;: I love carrying this lightweight kindle and reading books";;;;;

Rating: 2.0 out of 5 stars,"Touch screen feature is unnecessary and problematic. And lacks a ""hold"" feature which would remedy the situation.I had a kindle keyboard for years and LOVED reading on it. But unfortunately for the touch screen and minimal non-touch sensitive space on the Kindle Touchscreen leaves you with little place to hold it. I consider my hands medium to smaller. There should be plenty of room on this thing to hold it. But there simply isn't. Meaning your hand has to hold smaller space and can cramp up.The kindle keyboard was great because you could hold the kindle and if your thumb rested on the page, it wouldn't affect the experience. And even though the physical keyboard was hardly ever used, it gave you more space to hold the device.Honestly, the problem could be fixed with a ""hold"" feature. If you remember iPods and cd players, they had a switch that when turned on, made it so buttons were unresponsive. So if they were inadvertently pushed, it didn't affect the experience. If the Kindle either had a physical switch or a mode from the software that made the kindle unresponsive until the power button or a specific corner of the screen was touched, it would completely fix the experience.But sadly the kindle Touch screen lacks this feature leaving me missing the discontinued Kindle Keyboard.",Touch screen feature is unnecessary and problematic;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I love this kindle.  I also own aFire HDX 8.9"", but I wanted a plain Kindle for just reading. This feels much lighter than my HDX and it is thinner.I am having trouble getting used to the feel of it in my hand but I will eventually.  I wanted to write this review because I am a person with dyslexia and I love that I can change the font and size of the print to accommodate those BayeSian having more difficulty reading. This model comes with the Futura font which is easiest for me to read. I wish that all Kindles and Fires offered all fonts.  I can not get this font on the HDX yet.  I have talked to customer service and it may be in an update but I don't understand why all the fonts aren't universal to all Kindles.Anyway, I love this Kindle. Yes, you need a lighted area to read in and you need Wi-Fi to download material. If you do not have Wi-Fi yourself, go to your local library or a McDonald's.  I did that with my first reader and that kept me going for 2 years.  Once I needed internet for college, I invested in Wi-Fi. As someone else mentioned, this is a great introductory Kindle.  I got mine during the Black Friday sales and it was under 70 dollars.  If you want a beginning reader for your children, you may want to get the Kindle he 6.  If your child is past picture books, then this Kindle is for you. Compare before you buy and you won't be disappointed.",Great Little E-reader. Want a light? Use a lamp.;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"My kindle first kindle broke after almost 4 years and I wanted to get a kindle that could be replaced if this one broke. So I went ahead and ordered this one.Knowing what it could and couldn't do from reading screaming reviews I thought I could handle it. I filled out the return form in less than ten minutes of using it.My last kindle was the Kindle Keyboard 3G, Free 3G + Wi-Fi, 6"" E Ink Display and I payed a heavy price of about $175. So given the time frame and electronics prices diminishing over time, $59 is were mine fell used (only no warranty so there's no guarantee I'll get 4 years out of it).So I bought this kindle because I don't want one with games, apps, or even black light, pretty simple.Pro's-Easier to deactivate your amazon account-Parent Locks-Screen looks like it has more gray pigment-Cloud Option (need WiFi but you should have enought room to hold everything)-email to kindle-can rent booksCon's-Smudges Insanely Easy-Hard to hold compare to the others (bulky and slick texture, much larger than older kindles)-Experimental Internet is different on amazon site (Not given the option to go to desktop screen and navigation is poor)-Can't get comfortable as easy without side buttons-Touch screen is iffy when trying to turn page there may be a delay-material of case is weak for being newer model(break easier)-no color for magazinesneutral-advertising (annoying, but you can pay for them gone)-encourages more media sharing about what you readLooks like I'm retiring from being a kindle user, there is the kindle app you can place on your laptop, phone, or tablet.Newer kindle users are impressed with device, old users are left frustrated.",Quality is worse on this kindle;;;;;;

Review: I am having a bit of a problem learning how to use it. I have to keep going back to the Guide to see how to get where I want to get. With my previous Kindle the buttons are right there. I am sure my age (76) has something to do with it. Perhaps after I have used it awhile it will get easier. I am not in to touch screens much. Yet!
Title;;;;;;: I am having a bit of a problem learning how ...;;;;;;

Review: I bought this one to replace the 4-year old one that finally died. The screen size is the same but they changed to dimensions of the outer frame just enough I couldn't use the protective case from the old one. There are a couple of minor differences in the controls but otherwise much the same.

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"I bought this to replace my broken 4th gen Kindle after having dropped it(oops!), and I couldn't be more happy.Aside from the battery life being somewhat less than is advertised(which is to be expected for a several hours a day reader like myself), this Kindle exceeds my expectations! I feel that the e-ink display is clearer than the previous generations. The processor is faster, making for smoother page transitions and faster searches.The added feature of Kindle Free Time is unnecessary for me as I am the only user, but a nice addition, and will be nice when we order one for our children to share when they get to be reading age.I love the ""time remaining in chapter/book"" feature. it's helpful to know when the chapter will end so I know how long I have so I have a set time I can set the Kindle down to cook dinner, or go to bed, since I'm an addicted reader that doesn't like to put a book down until I've reached a good stopping point.",and I couldn't be more happy. Aside from the battery life being somewhat less ...;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"I'm not impressed. I've spent the better part of THREE HOURS trying to set this up as a gift for my roommate. All I can say is thank goodness I'm the one setting it up and not her. If she had to go thru all of this hassle, she would have asked me to return it. Definitely not what I expected. Am sorely disappointed.",Not worth the cost;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I love it. I read fast and enjoy having the full control of size, font & alignment. How I like to read my letters just speeds up the reading time. The fast access to dictionary is amazingly beneficial for easier & faster learning. I only regret not buying it sooner.",Too much greatness for the price;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I am really enjoying my Kindle. I already had a Kindle Fire HD, however, it strained my eyes too much to read at night. The size is perfect to carry around with me. And, I have to be honest here, I'm a big Star Trek geek, and the Kindle reader reminds of the PADD device on that show.",Best e-reader in the galaxy.;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"I was really looking forward to the touch screen, but it's ended up being really annoying. I like to read holding the Kindle one handed, but even holding it with both hands, or even holding it in one hand and using the index finger of the other hand (the most careful way to tap the touch screen) when I tap the right side to advance a page, it often jumps forward several pages. And it is incredibly annoying to have to page back to the page I was trying to get to in the first place. Jerks me right out of the book. It's annoying enough that I wish I'd kept my old, non touch screen Kindle. It seems to be confined to page turning, so when I need to use the on screen keyboard it works great. And that's the reason I upgraded. Still, having a hard to use keyboard is *much* preferable to this ""jump ahead several pages"" thing. Oh well, live and learn.","Touch screen is ""touchy"" Even a very careful tap can have it advancing several pages instead of just 1 when trying to turn pages";;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I took advantage of the trade in program to get the extra $25 toward a new kindle. I boxed up my old one and sent it off to Amazon. After they accepted it, I ordered the new touch screen model.Why an e-ink reader? Well, I travel a lot for work and like to read. I already stare at LCD screens all day so the e-ink is softer on my eyes. Why kindle? Well, no matter how you look at it, the Amazon ecosystem is top notch.So, how does the latest version stack up?  First off, the software is touch friendly and a little easier to get around.  You can long press a word to get a definition instead of navigating to it via a button.  You can press the top of the screen to get back to your home screen and choose a new reading material.  Want to read a book? Just tap it to open it.  Turn a page? Tap it and give a little swipe in the direction you want to go (swipe it left to go to the next page, right go back to a previous page. It works pretty well and seems very snappy. I would argue that the screen is not as sensitive as a phone or iPad, but that is a good thing.See, the touch can get in the way at times. I have accidentally turned the more than I ever did on my old Kindle.  I would almost be in favor of a hardware button to accomplish this. Kind of annoying, but I can live with it.  My other ""issue"" deals with the sleep /wake button.  It is on the bottom of the device and I have accidentally hit that a few times while reading.  I wish that, while in a book,  Amazon would use the button to trigger a dialog box that popped up asking if that was an accident or if you really wanted to send the device into sleep.Overall, I am impressed. I like the reader. The screen is sharp and responsive. The touch screen can be both an upgrade and an annoyance, but overall I prefer it.  I am glad I updated.",I travel a lot for work and like to read;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"When I saw that this had gone on sale, I had to buy it. I bought this device for $59 with special offers, which is an amazing price. This device is amazing and is far better than my old Kindle Keyboard. This device has a touchscreen, which I was not happy about at first. It turned out to be the best feature of this device (After reading of course). The touchscreen uses infrared which made the screen very sensitive, sometimes too sensitive. It is pretty good though and has no input lag except for the e-paper display. It makes navigation so much easier than on the Kindle Keyboard. The screen quality is pretty good, too. It never glares and I can read it in direct sunlight. The screen quality is decent as well. You can see books and even read large PDF's. It just works. This device is fast and never seems to slow down. It opens books fast, it opens the Kindle Store fast, and it also opens Goodreads fast. The Kindle Store has the most e-books of any online store. The books/magazines are affordable and download quickly. When you open a book on the device, you can change the margins, font size, and the font style. The reading experience is quite nice. It feels like I am reading a very light and thin book. It does not hurt your eyes like an LCD on a smartphone or tablet, it is just like reading a book off of the real paper. The Goodreads integration is great and I like to use it a lot. It is good for writing reviews right on the Kindle after finishing the book. Also, it is good for reading other people's reviews and suggestions. You can even set what book you reading at the time. The keyboard contributes to both the Kindle Store and Goodreads. The keyboard, I think, is even better than the Kindle Keyboard. It is fast and responsive (Other than the screen) and can take actions quickly. It also pops up fast as well. This is THE best thing I have ever read on. It is even better than a normal book because it is so light and thin. I did not talk about some of the features because I do not personally use them. In conclusion, this is a great device for reading and I would recommend it to anyone even compared to other e-readers.",Best Reading Device Ever!;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"When my trusty Kindle III Keyboard finally seemed to be giving up the ghost, I finally decided to upgrade. I almost wish I'd bought a rebuilt Kindle III.  The new version's okay, but I'm not that crazy about the touchscreen feature.  Too often, I'll try to flick off a crumb or something, and find myself on a different page.  My cat even changed pages when she flicked her tail at the screen and hit it just right.  My major complaint, however, is that I can no longer listen to books unless they have Whispersync, and I can only get that where there's wi-fi.  That means, unless I buy the audio version, I can't listen to the book I've been reading while I drive or when I'm doing volunteer work at the VA.  Those spots are about as cold as you get.  The voice on my old Kindle was rather robotic and pronounced words strangely sometimes, but it worked.  I was able to listen to books in the basement of the VA while my arms were in a warm-sand treatment for carpal tunnel and arthritis.  Whispersync doesn't work down there, and reaching the screen with my nose isn't all that great when I want to change the page.The unit is also smaller than my old one, and is not made to fit into the same case.  I'm sure that's Amazon's way of selling more cases, but I can't afford one.  Overall, I wish my old one worked better.  It seems as though every time someone upgrades technology, they make it worse, not better.",Not as Good as its Predecessor;;;;;;

2.0 out of 5 stars,"This Kindle -- the so-called ""new and improved"" is a huge step backwards for me, from the older Kindle I had with the touch buttons at the bottom. With that one, it was super easy to navigate. With the older one, when I was finished reading a book, I simply sent it to the Archieves by pressing a button -- it didn't clutter up the main screen where I kept the lsit of unread books. And when I bought a new book, it showed up only on my main screen, and at the top of the list. And if I wanted to delete a book for good and not keep it either on the main screen or in Archieves, that was easily accomplished by pushing a couple of buttons.None of that is easily done on the new and disimproved model. Firsts and foremost complaint, there are no written instrucitons. What good is it to have instrucitons buried somewhere in your new device, without any instrucitons on how to access the instrucitons? Amazon quite sending out owner's manuels because that costs them a little money to have it printed outI on paper, so they save a little on each sale by not doing that.  But it makes it so much harder to try and learn how to operate the new Kindle without having the instrucitons at your side to help you. So now I will have to go to Amazon and buy one.  I can not delete a book, except to hook up the !@#$%^&^! thing to my computer and try to delete it from there. I can not seem to switch a read book out of the books queue to the cloud, so the books on ""Book"" list just keeps growing.I could go on and on with complaints, but it is so bad----(how bad is it?) I have stopped even trying to use it, and have gone to a different e-reader instead. Too bad, Amazon. Too bad, Kindle. It was great while it lasted, but nooooooooo. You had to go and really mess up a easy to understand, easy to use, perfectly good device, and really screw it up with your so-called ""dis-improvementsw"".Sign me,Very dissatisfied","The 6"" Glare-Free Touichscreen Kindle is a HUGE step backwards";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"This is my fifth Kindle.  All the others died of a shattered screen except my first generation and my Kindle Fire HD.  My first generation Kindle is simply so hard to handle and use compared to later models that it spends most of its time in the closet. most of my other Kindles were the keyboard type. (model D00901)  I loved them, but the screens were too fragile, and the four-way navigation switch was so tiny that I needed a special tool to use it. So, for my fourth kindle, I got a Kindle Fire HD.My Kindle Fire is an amazing device, but it has several drawbacks.  The worst drawback is that the moment I step outdoors, the screen goes dim and the faint image that remains is totally lost in the glare from the very shiny screen.  I have a handicap that prevents me from driving so I travel a lot by bus, which means that I spend a lot of time waiting at bus stops.  I like to carry a Kindle with me to read while waiting, so I need one that works outdoors.  It just happens that a local store happened to have a used touch screen Kindle on sale at a very low price.As other commenters have said, it came without a wall plug adapter, but this was no problem since I still had the adapters from the old broken Kindles, as well as the adapter from my Kindle fire HD.  All of these are usable on my touchscreen except for the first generation. In addition, my local supermarket carries a pack of various USB connectors and an adapter that works just as well, so I didn't have to send for an Amazon adapter.Going from a keyboard to touch screen did take some learning time and I am still learning some things.  Luckily, this Kindle, unlike the Kindle Fire, comes with a complete and easy to read users guide. the more I use the touchscreen, the more assured I am that I will never go back to the keyboard.You will need a couple accessories.  If you want to keep your screen clean and free of fingerprints, you need a stylus.  Basically, this appears to be an aluminum tube with a soft rubber tip on one end, and a pocket clip on the other.  unlike your fingers, the rubber does not generate skin oils and is easy to wipe clean of any dirt it may pick up.  Also, since the point of the stylus is much smaller than your fingertip, it is much more accurate.  I was able to order a pack of about twenty of these for a couple bucks from an auction site in china, which gave me plenty to share with friends and still have lots of spares.The one absolutely necessary accessary is a cover.  Your Kindle is a fragile device, and needs to be protected from rough handling, weather, and the other things in your purse.  There are many different kinds of covers available online and at local electronic stores.  First, pick one that fits your model of kindle.  Different models of Kindle have on/off, volume control, and wireless switches in different places. the wrong cover may prevent access to these switches.  Second, pick one that is very sturdy.  Mine came with a neoprene bag which offered some protection from shock, but did nothing against bending stress. Bending stress is a main cause of shattered screens, and a shattered screen turns your Kindle into a very expensive piece of trash. The stronger your case, the safer your kindle is, so get the best cover you can afford.My touch screen Kindle is the best I've ever owned. For a person buying their first Kindle, or a person who wants a handy, go everywhere reading device, look no farther.  The only improvement that I would like to see is to make one with a seven or eight inch screen. I am a fast reader and would like one where I do not have to turn the page so often.","(model D00901) I loved them, but the screens were too fragile";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"You read, you need a kindle! There is nothing like a kindle for reading. I have own every kindle there is and have tried every other reader around. My choice for reading is the plain and simple kindle. Yes I like the paper white and the fancy voyage for the back light and higher resolution. But there is something special in the plain kindle 6, it just feels and reads more like a book.",There is nothing like a plain kindle 6 for reading.;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I got this thing as a refurb and it's basically brand new. I can see nothing that would suggest much use for sure. No problems with the screen as of now and the touch mechanism to me is working perfectly. Updating the thing was a breeze. So let's get into detail on the device...The normal Kindle I suppose is the poor man's e-reader at this point in Amazon's lineup. But I am waiting until the 16nm tablet revolution to get one of their high-end tablets. I didn't want to pay more than I needed for something that I just read text on, and the paperwhite seems to have its fair share of screen problems. This one was only 64 dollars base price. I got a used case to go along with it.For that price the device is positively charming. It's my first Kindle and I really could not ask for more. Amazon's software if very mature at this point, so you have a variety of fonts, readability settings, and core attributes to modify to your liking. After a couple minor fixes for my own personal use I was off downloading my entire Kindle on PC library. Easy. Fast. I could not ask for anything easier. The experimental browser also gets the job done. Bookmarks and decent website compatibility as long as it doesn't use too much Flash or Java. The device works perfectly for a college accessory and textbook device when needed.Not all textbooks are compatible with the lower end devices though. That was the only downside to the cheapest one in the lineup. My Glossary of Literary Terms was sadly not okay with this e-reader.Navigating and using features like highlights, x-ray, dictionaries, and the page functions took about 20 minutes for me to get the hang of it all. Again, everything is set up to help the customer get up and running very easily. The various swipes are easy to remember and incredibly intuitive at this point. I can flip, preview, cancel, and just all around enjoy the book I am reading without hardly any hassle at all. I for one did not think the page turning was too sensitive on mine. Seems about right for such a device. Amazon clearly has some very mature software here that complements the Kindle hardware in synergistic fashion.I don't use too many of the community features like Goodreads, but that is there for you too if you want to be involved in the gigantic Kindle community. Other great community functions that are less pervasive include notes on what people highlighted in the book, which I found to be a nice feature. And then you have other functions like about the book, which gives you some really nice info about what you are reading the first time.The one thing some people are going to not like is probably the storage. 4GBs is not really what I call enough space for the future. Luckily, I do have a lot of Delphi collections and my books fit on here nicely at this point. I have about 2.3GBs left after DL'ing 70 or so products. Amazon itself has its own helpful user guide for you to DL right off the bat, so if you do ever get lost that thing should save you a lot of time.The resolution of the display seems fine to me and very close to what you would get in a normal sized book. The somewhat dim display works very well for and is basically about the brightness of a normal literature page. I was comparing it to a bunch of my books and came away quite pleased with what they have here. Of course a bit more resolution would be nice, but for what is here you can still get fairly small fonts and good detail. This is not a reader for the dark, obviously.Anyway, I don't think there is too much else to say. I'll update the review as I go along, and take a note on battery life, but for now this thing is a great little device. Cheap, fast, easy to use, and all around a nice product to own with good and simple build quality. It sync'd up with my Amazon account right away and there was absolutely zero trouble getting this thing to work correctly. Highly recommended to those on a budget or to those that do not have any need for the higher-end tablets and readers. Unlike some of the other products, this one doesn't have any inherent screen issues, either.",A nifty device.;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"This is my fifth or sixth Kindle over the years. While I am a bit old-fashioned and love having a good old paper book, this kindle works for me. Life changes for us all, and mine is no exception. We downsized from a good-sized home in the suburbs to an apartment in the city. Gone is the luxury of having an extra room to serve as an office and ""library"".I feel lost if I'm traveling without something to read. There always seems to be some sort of delay. Whether waiting for a plane or train, or just the doctor, having a book handy is always the perfect remedy. Having a Kindle is even better, because it's quick and easy to switch to something that I feel like reading at that particular moment.I have had a couple of the other ""glare free""  or paper white kindles and have always loved them. They all met their end due to serious use, and ultimately, something dumb on my end.
