3.0 out of 5 stars,"Very easy and nice to read, lightweight and size is great, the one with light is really better, but plastic cover is too soft and breakable so you must take extremely care or buy an extra cover for make it durable.",Great product to read but take extra care as too soft and breakable;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"Wonderful reader!Was surprised at how lightweight it is.  I love reading and this little gadget makes reading my books easy - and super portable.  I was able to pick up a nice little black cover for it to keep it nice and protected.  Travels light - fits in my back pocket.Trick to the battery life - after opening your book of the hour, place on airplane mode.",Loving it!!;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"My older Kindle died on me and this was the cheapest and simplest replacement unit I could fine.  I was used to using buttons to turn the page, access the menu, etc.  This unit has screen sensitivity.  While it is much faster than the older Kindle, I find that it is difficult to avoid inadvertent screen touches that change the page or change the fond or something else.  The surface of the frame, front and back, is smooth and slippery.  It would have been very helpful to have used a rubberized surface.",OK - But Difficult to Hold / Use;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"If you want a good e reader, this is just fine.  No glare on the screen as with a tablet.  It is not lit in any way, so you need to read it like a print book - with lighting.  Responds well to touch, so turning pages is easy, as is looking up words and notes.  I downloaded a Shakespearean play, and the notes were underlined for easy reference.  You can access the notes and translations to modern English with one touch. I haven't used x-ray yet.  Download is quick, even with a so-so internet connection.  The device is comfortable to hold.  I have mine in a book-type case.Pro:  Easy to read screen.  Comfortable and light.  Easy to navigate.  Responsive. Reasonable price.Con:  No audio for audible books.  No internal light may be a con for some, but not for me.","If you just want to read with it, it's a great choice.";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"Bought this for our 10 yr old daughter for her birthday. She just loves it! She really loves the kindle free time function of it, where she can earn badges by meeting reading goals. As a parent, it's great, because you can decide which books are available on kindle free time, and there is a password required to leave kindle free time. Essentially, you can control which books they have access to.There is also a parental controls section where you can turn off options such as access to the kindle store, you can limit or exclude access to your personal library so kids cannot access your adult books.Battery life is great! Controls are super easy, it's all touch screen. It also has a built-in dictionary that doesn't require wifi access.",Great for parents AND kids!;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"The Kindle is light weight and easy to handle. I have  had fun going to various e-book sites and browsing. I've found quite a number of free books I like. Not being a techy, it took me a while to get the hang of it. I think it is going to be a lot of fun to own.",The Kindle is light weight and easy to handle;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"Amazing dedicated e-reader.First off I want to say that I had complications syncing some books that aren't directly from amazon. Initially I downloaded them to my computer and then transferred them to the kindle via a USB cable, but this did not sync them to the cloud. In order to sync them you must email the file to your kindle, this will then sync the books to your library. You can find the email of your kindle by going to Settings -> Device Options ->Personalize Your Kindle. Under Send-to Kindle Email it will display the email you should send your books to. Once you email the files they will automatically load onto your device and sync across all devices.So far I am impressed by the device and will probably enjoy much more reading in the future. Being able to just have the book with you in a few seconds without having to obtain a physical copy is really useful.Additionally, it's also really useful being able to tap and hold on a word and having it's dictionary definition pop up.","Great Device, In order to sync non-Amazon ebooks, email the file to your kindle.";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"Bought this as my wife's Valentines Day present! She had an OLD Kindle that was so primitive it made me cringe watching her use it. Yhis Kindle is easy to operate and the pages are white, just like the pages of a novel or magazine. I am going to buy one for me!",My wife loves Kindling!;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"These Kindles have worked great with my kids. As parents, our favorite part is that we immediately logged each one we received into Kindle FreeTime and had the books we'd already assigned to their profiles show up. You know. Safe books. Not the plethora of free erotica floating around Amazon's cloud (sheesh). We then got to snicker as we watched our kids whine and complain that they couldn't get into apps (like you can on the Kindle Fire) and play Minecraft 24/7. We're evil like that. A minute later, they'd figured out the simple touch screen commands and found the books and then they disappeared to read some of their favorites. Blessed, blessed quiet. Thank you Amazon.","No, You Can't Kill Zombies - But You Can Read!";;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"Five months and many books later, I haven't changed my opinion of this Kindle reader. I would gladly trade it in for an earlier model.Maybe I'm old school, but this Kindle is inferior to my older one:1. I miss the page turn ""paddles"" that made my previous Kindle so easy to read. I now have to touch the screen in the ""right"" area to turn pages.2. With my old Kindle, I could dive deeper and deeper into the Dictionary and pop out when I was done. With my new Kindle, I get a first level definition, but no ability to define words in the definition or link to related topics. I also can't type in words to explore as I'm reading.3. My new Kindle is subject to unintended interactions via the touch screen. I don't know about you, but I often read before I go to sleep, or, more precisely, as I'm going to sleep. This means that I may interact with the screen when my fingers slip or my glasses fall off or .... I too often jerk awake and discover that the font has been adjusted to microscopic or gigantic or that I've paged forward or backward to some indeterminate point in the book I'm reading.Overall, I preferred the previous Kindle, whose screen broke when I dropped it on a hard floor as I fell asleep. I don't think the touch screen has enhanced my reading experience overall.",Kindle Touch Screen not an Improvement;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"Unfortunately my last kindle got left at a hotel that refused to send it to me (that bad review went on another site) so when I went to get a new one, I had to go with the new touchscreen version.  Not that it's bad...it's just different. I like my kindle as simple as can be-I use it to read books and nothing more, and had no issue using the side buttons.  The finger swipe took a bit to get used to.  The new kindle is also bulkier...due to the touch technology, I'm sure, but I liked the light, sleek design of the last version.Lastly...they say pages turn much faster...but if anything, the page turn feels a bit slower to me, and after using the device only a couple times, it's already been freezing on me a bit.  At the base of it, the kindle is still the best ereader out there (in my opinion) and when this one eventually goes, either through technical failure or loss, I'll surely get another...but I've gotta say, I do miss the last generation a bit.",... hotel that refused to send it to me (that bad review went on another site) so when I went ...;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I have owned a kindle keyboard for the past 3 + years and have really liked it but I started getting black lines on pages and have to flip back and forth to get rid of it. Since I am unsure how long it will chug along I decided to bite the bullet when this was on sale. I will say that the pages are much easier to read on this Kindle and can even read in sunlight which I had trouble doing on my other one. This Kindle is much lighter but I actually prefer it a bit heavier. Touchscreen very responsive but I do prefer the physical buttons. I realize that everything is going to touchscreen and most folks prefer that, but am of the AARP generation and change is not always my friend. I did find that I kept accidentally turning pages at times so I got a case which seems to help and adds a bit of volume which feels better to me since it is so much smaller than kindle keyboard. One of the definite improvements is that apparently your collections are kept in the cloud so when I have to eventually replace it won't have to spend all that time reforming my collections. My one big complaint is the reading progress option. My old kindle has small black vertical lines along the bottom so you can see progress in each chapter. This kindle gives the options of locations, time left in chapter or book, or nothing. Hate the locations option since it means nothing to me. How about an actual page number option? As far as the time left in chapter it is way off. It currently shows I have one or two minutes left of reading but still have at least 6 or 7 pages left. Apparently my kindle thinks I'm a speed reader extraordinaire. These are just minor annoyances and I can easily live with them since it's so convenient and easy to use. Battery life is very good. Depending on how much I'm reading charge can last for one week (if reading a lot) or a lot longer if not reading too much. Battery will drain much faster if you leave WiFi on so I just turn it on occasionally to sync or to download a book. Setup is very easy. Just make sure to have WiFi available and know how to connect to it or you will be really frustrated. I would also recommend getting a cover for it to keep screen clean and help prevent you from accidentally turning pages.12/18 Update. Well I don't know if just coincidence but I received an update today. You now have the option for a page number. Thanks Amazon!",Pretty good;;;;;;

Review: I am completely in love with this product of kindle. It's not bulky and not even of odd size. You can hold it for hours and feel just like you are reading the book. The text appears just the way you see them in a book. It's glare free and I was amazed to see it and read in it because I hate reading the ebooks and was against buying it but my husband insisted that we should atleast try it to see and decide and now we literally fight to get our turn to read on this amazing device. One more thing the charge of this kindly device is for days it's been 4 days and u have lot charged it and I read for almost 2 hrs daily.I strongly recommend it

Rating: 1.0 out of 5 stars,"Wish my old Kindle hadn't died because this 7th-generation version is awful.  First unit would not access the network, second would not hold a charge.  This does work, but the User's Guide is totally worthless.  For starters, it can't be accessed if the unit isn't working.  Yes, I can go to the computer and the on-line pages - IF I am at home.  But the on-line pages are worthless, too.User's guide doesn't answer a lot of basic questions, such as how to make the reader show page numbers instead of locations or time remaining to finish the book.Downloading books or other items from the Cloud to the device must be done one item at a time.  Even at 30 seconds per item, for my 263 items that's more than two hours.  So, I'm supposed to download just what I want for the next few days - BUT I PAID FOR ALL 263 ITEMS and I don't always know which one I'm going to want two days from now.  So, I'm supposed to buy a 3G unit which can access the network when I'm away from home - why didn't Amazon tell me that before I paid nearly $100 for this version - and why should I have to keep spending more and more money to access what I have already paid for?  For me, it's back to hard-copy books except when I'm going on an overseas trip - and by my next overseas trip I'll have investigated competitors in hopes of finding one that is truly customer-centered and less exploitative than Kindle.",Expensive hunk of junk!;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"not much better than the previous one I had - the Paperwhite. Basically same features - just reconfigured - except for the touchscreen system;  the buttons have disappeared. No problem with that except that the screen is ultra sensitive. If you so much as breath heavily on it
Review: or try to swipe off dust or hair
Title;;;;;;: your screen will change.  Very annoying. With the undisplayed menu it is hard to remember where things are
column4: but keep tapping everywhere on the screen until you find what you want. you spend so much time tapping the screen instead of getting ahead with your reading.  this is the problem with technology updates - just as you have mastered your device
column5: it conks out and you have to replace it with another and learn everything about it;" conks out
column6: buy another
column7: learn the buttons. repeat.  Same with software - you have not even used or learned half of when yet another version appears and you feel medieval if you don't buy it.""
column8: Too sensitive touchscreen";;;;

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"No, I am not a dinosaur, but I do have a vision challenge. Took me this long to buy a reader because I was concerned it would be harder to read than print on paper. Turns out to be so much easier to read. Totally unlike a laptop or tablet screen.Wish I had bought my Kindle years ago. I now give them as gifts to my dinosaur friends.",Wish I Had Not Waited So Long!;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"To be honest, I have always been very wary of having any eReader.  I have found the technology of electronic ink to be fascinating, and have been interested in eReaders for a while, but I just love the feel and convenience of an actual BOOK.Then my wife won a Kindle at a contest and gave it to me.I have to admit, I do love it.  It is much easier for me to find the books I want to read, and the touch screen makes it easy to navigate.  The best part is the fact that I can look up works or wikipedia articles by just tapping on a word or phrase.  I can highlight phrases and bookmark them to come back later (which has been very useful in books rife with latin).  I can translate words of other languages in the same manner.  And if I run into a word I don't know, it saves it to the ""vocabulary builder"" so that I can look it up later and actually improve my vocabulary.  With the ability to scroll through pages quickly, it turns out that the Kindle is just as convenient to navigate as a book and more convenient when it comes to dictionaries and the like.  While I *do* miss having page numbers, I like enjoy seeing the percentage of a book I have completed.  While my eReader will not replace books for me, it is a very good supplement to them, another format that I will enjoy.",Convert;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"CAME FAST, EASY TO USE, just bought a KINDLE from Amazon, LOVE IT, SO COOL, downloading free books and books for under 2.00, awesome to have a library going on in my pocket. (almost said pants smile emoticon ) i recommend you all get one it is awesome.","I SUGGEST YOU ALL GET ONE, NEVER THOUGHT IT WOULD BE SO AWESOME HAVING A LIBRARY IN YOUR POCKET";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I have been a kindle owner for the past 5 years until this past June when my keyboard kindle died and since the price was good and in desperate need to get one again, I bought the new kindle and I'm loving it so far! It was fairly easy to work but it is kinda weird not having the keyboard around anymore but it does make it much easier to work knowing there is only one button on the device now instead of 30 or more. Granted I only had it for a day but I'm seeing a much improvement in my reading over reading on a phone. Hopefully this will last me for the next 4 or 5 years and when this one dies, I will be back to buy a new kindle whatever that may be!",Awesome Device For Bookworms!!;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I have been addicted to my Kindle for years now, and I'm pleased to report that the younger generation did not let me down. A few things need getting used to. It downloads, for example, not via the nearly ubiquitous cellular signal, but via the internet. If you're at home and have wifi, all the better. If you're in a public space, the wi fi may be nonexistent or expensive, and may be especially inconvenient for people like me who download a daily newspaper. On the other hand, I'm assuming that connecting via the web, newspaper readers will no longer be hit with weekly access fees when travelling abroad. A fair trade.The device itself is smaller, lighter, and every bit as agile as my previous Kindle. The display is crisper, and pages turn instantly with the lightest of touch. Navigation is robust, though it takes some trial and error to find all the available functionality. Best of all the price has gone down.Only one carp: why exactly did my previous Kindle suddenly die after several years of dependable operation? Planned obsolescence? Could it have been repaired? No matter how nifty the product, a long life trumps unneeded innovations.",and I'm pleased to report that the younger generation did not let ...;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I picked this up used to use as a PDF reader as eInk displays are easier for some of the things I do (black and white technical documentation). I did not intend to actually read books with this. I started messing around with it, put one of my PDF technical eBooks on it (old out of copyright electrician's book that Google scanned) and was actually disappointed with the display performance. I rightly suspected the book's scan was poor and started playing around with the Experimental browser and was instantly reassured of the display's quality. Then I decided it was time to look at some of the books I got on Kindle Apps in the past (mostly free classics). I quickly discovered I couldn't stand to read Tale of Two Cities without the discussions we had in English Class back in the day. I set out and bought a few small eBooks about some things I was interested in and read them (small books), I then decided that eBook reading is right for me which I never would have suspected.The only downside is the experimental browser needs a little work. I don't expect Miracles, but I would like to be able to read news sites without it crashing. I didn't expect this feature at purchase, but if this were updated a bit so I could read CNN, Fox News, BBC, etc without the browser crashing out it would be perfect.Rundown:Display: Exceeds expectations, sharper than I imagined, sharp as or sharper than a printed pageConnectivity: Excellent, WiFi and USB connectivity that works out of the box on a Mac.Content Availability: Perfect, Content from Amazon and from PDF files can easily be loadedEase of use: took me a few minutes to learn, but perfect.Browser: Needs work, but not really the reason you buy one of theseLastly, I now love reading, I used to be like ""Who has time and space for books,"" now I can actually read and enjoy it.",You will regret not buying this sooner.;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I was looking for a reader for outside.  As far as the extras?  I already have prime, so those didn't determine my choice.  Great little instrument, lightweight, fits in purse.  Bought a cover to protect it, found one thru amazon for $20 just to protect it.  Nice cover.",Recommend for someone that just wants a reader with no bells and whistles.;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"The Kindle E-Reader makes reading so enjoyable.  I love being able to hold up this very light weight device, without trying to hold pages open at the same time.  It is so easy to use, and I love that I can take hundreds of books with me wherever I go.  The Kindle E-Reader was a revolutionary device years ago, but it still holds up today as a great device, even in a world of iPads, iPad Mini's, iPhone Plus, Android Tablets and smaller laptops.  The lack of strain on your eyes when reading makes this a much better e-book reading device than all the other tablets out there.",Still relevant in a world of tablets;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"After years of debate, we broke down and got ourselves two kindles. The basic model but 7th gen. Exactly what we need and wanted. No back lighting, but hey that's why there's the sun and/or lamps, right? :)",Love Them (2)!;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"This review is targeted to those completely new to kindles since I noticed most of the other reviews seem to assume familiarity with other kindle products.My background: For the past five years I've been doing most of my book reading on either my iPad or iPhone (yes, I find reading books on my phone quite comfortable actually!). The problem with both of them is the LIGHT, they're just too shiny to read in bed while I'm trying to fall asleep(even with the ""invert colors"" option turned on). It was either get more and more paper books (inconvenient), or try something else. Hence, the basic kindle.I chose the basic kindle because despite reading a ton of reviews, I couldn't figure out what was so great about the kindle Paperwhite(119$) or kindle Voyager(199$) compared with $79 for the basic kindle. They have more bells and whistles but the core functionality appears to be the same. So far I think I made the right choice.CONS(1) It feels very cheap and plastic compared to an iPad. But this is not surprising considering the price difference.(2) The screen responds very slowly. Scrolling through a large amount of text is PAINFUL. But in reality this is not a problem since page turning inside a book is really the only thing you need to do most of the time and that part is fine.(3) If you don't pay the extra 20.00 you get ads at the bottom of the home screen. But these ads are not too obtrusive. I don't plan on paying.PROS(1) The screen is PERFECT for reading in bed because it emits NO LIGHT. It's the same as reading a paperback. Of course you would need to have a lamp on, but I think that's good as I don't think reading in the dark with just the light from an electronic device would be good for your eyes.(2) You can browse and buy books directly from the kindle. Warning: Your account is charged and books download INSTANTLY when you click ""Buy"", there is no confirmation screen. This is convenient if you know exactly what you want, but it's easier to do browsing on a regular computer due to the aforementioned painfully slow screen.(3) Easy to use, stays charged for a long time(I haven't tested their claim of ""weeks"", but based on the low power usage I could believe it), automatically syncs across all your kindle device, all the good things you would expect.Overall, I think this is good value if you(1) Read books in the sun where screen glare could be a problem.(2) Want to read in bed and don't like the bright light from from most electronic displays.I can't say if the other more advanced kindle versions are worth the extra money, but so far I'm liking this one.",A Review for total Kindle newbies;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"Okay, truth be told, I think the best e-reader on the market is the kindle paperwhite. Hands down. However, I got the regular kindle on sale for $30 cheaper than the current retail. So of course I'm going to get this one instead of the paperwhite.The entry level kindle is not bad, and honestly, I like this one better than the previous generation, which is what my boyfriend has. I don't know why some people have a hard time navigating this kindle because I have had no problems with it. Yes, sometimes I double click on a page by mistake but I can easily swipe back. And I like how I can touch the top of the screen so I can get to the main menu. Truth be told, I am a slow learner with electronics and I thought this version is easier to navigate than the last version. With the last version, I had a hard time going back and forth to the main menu and worrying about losing my place. Not with this kindle. And it's so easy for me to put bookmarks on this device! That way I can flip through different pages and books and go back to where I'd like to read!And I like that this kindle is easy on the eyes. Previously I was reading on my iPad, which was such a pain. The anti-glare makes it so easy to zip through the pages.Other tidbits:- no backlight. Kinda wish it did, but this is the ""economy"" kindle. Don't expect to read this in dim lighting.- make sure you download overdrive or your local library's app so you can send kindle-friendly books directly to your kindle! I've borrowed several books that were transferred on my kindle. No worries on late fees since the book is automatically returned when the loan period is up.- I don't know why Amazon shows videos of all their kindles hovering over water. This thing is NOT waterproof, but I think most people know that.- you can browse the Internet on a kindle but I don't recommend it. For some moronic reason I did that out of curiosity and it froze my kindle. Should've known better given that it's 4 GBs.Overall, I'm pretty satisfied with my kindle! I expect to read on it for many years to come!",Easy Reader;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I already had the  several Nooks but after getting Amazon Prime I decided to get an Kindle for the free monthly book loan program.  The Kindle special offers are shown on the locked page. The ads do not interfere with reading a book. With WiFi the books are easily downloaded. There is no glare in the sunlight.  Tap the edge to turn the paper, nothing easier.  The added dictionary is great. What I like most is the ability to get information on the characters with just a touch.Update: 03/08/2015I had stopped using the actual Kindle for about a month. Through  Prime  Free Book  download , the book is only available on the actual Kindle not through the Kindle app on my phone.  Fine, but I carry my phone more than my Kindle.When I wanted to go read the book I had down loaded. I realized I forget the correct name. It took a few minutes to find the book.It would be nice if the Kindle had a recent read tab.  If it's been a while, the recent read tab will still have the book near the top. At the present time the only categories are by recent download , Author or collection.It is nice that PDF formatted books are able to be downloaded.  So many Authors allow you to get their book free online. I download on my phone and send to my Kindle. It appears as a Doc on the Kindle and on the phone app.Other than the problem reading Free  Prime book, I am extremely pleased with the Kindle. So much so that I have ordered the Kindle Fire for my Daughter who  preference had been her Nook HD.",With WiFi the books are easily downloaded. There is no glare in the sunlight;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"As somebody who is a book lover, I have always resisted the readers.  There's just something about holding a book in your hands and smelling the pages.  (I know, I'm a nerd!)  But with a purse that already weighs more than it should, carrying around my current book isn't always feasible.  That is why I gave in to the social pressure and decided to give the Kindle a try.  Needless to say, I'm not disappointed.  I've had the unit for nearly a month now and while I don't use it everyday, I certainly do use it with regularity- but I have yet to charge it from it's original charge!  Blew my mind!!  While that alone makes it amazing, having access to a virtual library in a unit that weighs the same as a paperback book is more than I can put into words!  I can even change the font, so if I forgot my cheaters I can still manage to read the words, and I literally just have to tap the screen to turn the page.  While I'm still not willing to give up the real thing, I definitely consider myself a fan of the Kindle!!",I'm not disappointed. I've had the unit for nearly a month ...;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I bought this when it was on sale for $20 off the usual price (lowering it to a price I was willing to pay in order to experiment with an e-reader).  I initially had the free offers version, but found that often the Kindle had trouble waking up from the ads when I swiped to start reading.  That was very annoying, so once I decided that I liked the Kindle and wanted to keep it I was really happy to find that I could just pay the $20 difference to have the Kindle updated to remove the ads.  Haven't regretted getting rid of them since. I wish there was a light built in, and if in the future I decide I need a new e-reader I'll probably want to get one with that feature, but for now I'm happy with my experiment.  I still really enjoy reading actual paper books, but I also like reading them on the Kindle.  It always remembers exactly where I am in the book, even if I have to check out an e-book more than once in order to finish reading it. That's a wonderful convenience.  I use this a lot on the go since it's small, relatively light and easy to use. My iPad is much more cumbersome and heavy. It doesn't go too many places with me any more.  This Kindle will display the pictures in a book, but not all that clearly.  It's not made for impressive graphics.  I'm okay with that.  This is just a good, basic way to read books.  If you've been thinking of trying one out, go for it.  Amazon gives you 30 days to decide whether to keep it or not.","That was very annoying, so once I decided that I liked the ...";;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"This kindle replaced my old keyboard style kindle when I fell and it went out of commission. I have had this one for about three weeks.  I love this new version but am having some frustration with the touch screen It has a hair trigger and too often I find wikipedia and other stuff popping up when I only wanted to turn the page. Sometimes it goes forward when I want to g back, and although I consistently set it to the font size I need, it somehow changes even when I am sure I was holding it only by the cover and not touching the screen. I have been using a kindle for about four years and would hate to do without. I assume that my new touch screen kindle and I will soon be comfortable friends.","I am optimistic, but...";;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"Great deal on this, it still costs more than a FIRE but this is a touch screen. I had last purchased a Kindle e reader in 2011 and it was one that had a small keyboard on the face of it as well as audio capability.  This new one does not have audio capability so totally discounts the ability to use Audible on this device.  I do not like full color devices to read with and for now this will do, but I am disappointed that my older Kindle died as it was perfect.  This one seems a bit smaller with the viewing area being smaller than my previous 6 inch kindle.  I don't mind the touch screen ability, but do dearly miss the audio capability.",Miss my old Kindle!;;;;;;

1.0 out of 5 stars,"I am very disgusted with the Kindles with the touchscreen.  A friend gave me a Kindle several years ago and I loved it.  It did give me good service for years before it finally just gave out.  The Kindle I had, you clicked the side (either side) to turn the page.  I could not afford a new one so my daughter gave me hers and got a Kindle Fire.  Her Kindle is only about 2 years old and I hate it!  With the old one I could find the last page I read without any problem.  This one jumps around or jumps to the first of the book and you have to search page by page to find where you were.  Sometimes when you press to turn the page it doesn't turn the page or skips ahead several pages.  Sometimes I don't even have to touch the screen and it turns the page.  With my old Kindle I could delete books I have already read.  This one I can not.  Now the only Kindle you offer without having to touch the screen cost $199!  I thought the policy of any company was to make better products (not worse products) at better prices.  Not so with Kindle!",Older Kindle's much better than the newer ones.;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I finally got a Kindle because I had to take a 3-week trip to Rotterdam from California. I knew I would never be able to carry as many books as I would need, especially since we were going to need to carry a number of things back with us. It was a long flight with layovers both ways, and sleeping was nearly impossible in the cramped plane.I loaded the Kindle with e-books (I had a collection by one of my favorite authors, and there are lots of free books to download, and I decided to try Kindle Ultimate while I was at it) and packed it into my computer bag. It saved my life during the flight and the trip both. My husband thinks I should have gotten the one with its own lighting, but now that I'm home again, access to a reading light is not an issue.The text is amazingly clear--really, my graphics geek husband marveled over it--and being able to adjust the size means that even if I've forgotten my reading glasses, I can still read. (They don't always make it from one room to the o... Read more",The Survival Guide to Overseas Flights: Buy a Kindle;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I've long been an e-reader skeptic.  However, after finally trying my wife's Kindle, I decided I had to get my own.  I'm thrilled with it, and here's why:Travel:  I read a lot, and I read fast.  I usually go through a book in the course of the plane flight alone.  Add a couple more books to cover the flight back and the trip itself, and the weight and volume start to add up.  With the Kindle, I can bring a dozen books and take up less than the weight and volume of one!Finding new authors: I found my favorite authors by borrowing books from the library in my teens.  Now that I'm in my forties, a lot of them have died or retired, and I've read everything they wrote.  New books are too expensive to gamble with beating Sturgeon's law, and with two kids I don't have the time to get to the library.  With the kindle, I can check out lots of library e-books without leaving the house, and find my next generation of favorites for purchase!",I found my favorite authors by borrowing books from the library in my ...;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I never thought I would trade in my books for an electronic reader but I was given the Kindle 6"" Touchscreen as a gift and I love it.  This device reads just like a book. Completely glare-free and the screen has the look of paper. Friends and co-workers, who have the Kindle Fire or more expensive readers, were so jealous of my Kindle when I whipped it out during a flight on a recent group business trip. It will be perfect for an upcoming vacation to China, where I would have otherwise had to pack several books for a two-week trip.One note: you will need an attachable lighting device if you would like to read from this in a dark space.",Perfect reader;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"This is an excellent Ebook reader. I also have an iPad but reading at night often keeps me up because of the backlight. I like the design of the kindle because it reads like a regular book and I sleep well after reading it. It also reads well in bright sunlight or in areas where there is a lot of glare. The pages are easy to turn with the touch screen display. Naturally, it is not as fast an an IPad but it serves its purpose and performs wonderfully. Compared to older Ebook readers, the page turns and general operation is faster so it feels more natural.",This is an excellent Ebook reader;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I was looking for a dedicated e-reader to avoid distractions from a tablet and the eye strain of a back-lit screen so I opted for the traditional Kindle. The offers are not at all distracting when turning it on and it's very responsive and easy to tweak and customize. It's light, even with a cover, and easy to read with just one hand on the subway and fits great in my coat pocket. I live in a new york apartment and I don't have the space for a ton of books that I want to read so I want to start using the Kindle for reading to save space and be able to take it when I travel. Years ago I traveled cross-country by train and the weight and bulk of even just a half dozen books was a pain. Out of 100 books on my wishlist, only 2 or 3 are not available on the Kindle and are cheaper so I can definitely see this as my go-to for reading books.",Love it as a straightforward e-reader;;;;;;

Review: I love this. I bought this to read my books outside without having the glare that tablets have and I'm very happy with it! Warning though it is just for books. That's all I wanted for but just saying it doesn't do what a tablet does.i would highly recommend kindle fire cheap and does just what I need.

Rating: 2.0 out of 5 stars,"I bought this on ""prime day"" (aka ""grandmas got for candy for you, oh wait that's just sugar free mints"" day), but should have just gone with a paperwhite (which would have been nice if they had put that one on sale!) I bought this one for me and a paperwhite for him. This one feels cheap, and the plastic on the back is hard whereas the material on the back of the paperwhite is smooth and is almost a rubberized serface. Also, it actually is MUCH nicer to have the light options of the paperwhite. The paperwhite feels much nicer and looks much nicer with the higher resolution screen and optional light. If you can afford the extra money just get a paperwhite, you'll be glad you did.",The paperwhite is much better and worth the extra $$;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"This is my first e-reader, and I LOVE it.  The touch screen is so convenient, and it keeps my place in the books I am reading.It's true the screen is not lit from within, but that's not a problem for me, as I don't like to read in the dark!  It's very easy to operate, and anyone could learn how to use it in no time at all.  I'm very pleased with this purchase, and I will purchase more Kindles in the future!",Great Product!;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I love the new Kindle book.  It is small enough to fit in my hand, light weight, reads so incredibly well, and is simplified.  Although I like my Kindle fire and my Samsung tablet, I tend to want to play more games than read.  With the book, all I can do is read....and it is so nice to have no distractions.  The screen is also wonderful.  I have no difficulty seeing the print, regardless of lighting.  The dictionary works well, the ""x-ray"" has been incredibly helpful, and I do really enjoy the vocabulary builder.  I have often ""gotten the meaning"" of a word from context as opposed to looking up the word in the dictionary.  The vocabulary builder has not only added to my vocabulary, but has also added shades of meaning to the text.  Thank you, Amazon, for a wonderful product.","I love my newest Kindle, the book...";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"This was much better than I thought it would.  I think I could have like some better instructions though being a first time kindle users.  It took some time to figure it out.  All in all I lover it.  I would recommend this to everyone.  This is a kindle to read, so don't think you will be able to internet stuff with it like a tablet for those of you that are use to that.  I can read outside with the sun and lot of light with no problem.  I got a light light to attach for the dark areas ( or it could be my eyes)","Kindle 6"" Glare-Free";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"Waited along time before I purchased a Kindle,  I did not think I really needed a e reader when I have at tablet and a PC,  I needed it, LOL !!, the reading experience is totally different . After working on  a PC all day and trying to read on a tablet it gave me dry eyes, this is so much better, it is easier to hold than my 7 or 9 inch tablet.  I love the fact it will fit in my purse.  If you are going to read or any length of time the Kindle is the way to go.  My battery life has been good also, after I download a book I just turn the wifi off, mine came with a partial charge and it only took a couple of hours to charge it to full.",Do Not Wait Buy A Kindle - Love It;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I love that Kindle Touch is still anti-glare. it's what I love best about it. The screen doesn't hurt my eyes which is very important for me. The touch screen is superfast. You barely have to touch it. It's very responsive.I only have issues with the font size and the wireless. I wish there was a font size between font size number 5 and 6, like in my first kindle. Font size number 5 is either too small or font size number 6 is too big. There is no middle ground.Plus, I wish there was a simple Turn Wireless Off option like in my first kindle rather than the Airplane Mode. Otherwise it's pretty cool.",Fast touch screen but issue with fonts;;;;;;

2.0 out of 5 stars,"This model is bit disappointing compared to my previous one with the physical keyboard. This model has many defficiencies copared to the old one, the worst of which is that it consistently flips pages on own which is very anoying. I loved my old kiddle with the keyboard and wish it were still available (new) for purchase. I am not agaist new technology but they went backwards with this one.",the worst of which is that it consistently flips pages on ...;;;;;;

3.0 out of 5 stars,"The screen is clear and bright as I knew it would be. But I miss the ""one handed"" convenience of the original Kindle, where I could hold the book in the palm of my hand and  use my thumb to turn the pages.  This worked great, whichever hand you wanted to use.This one definitely takes two hands to use -- one to hold the device and one to hold the stylus, or to touch the screen. Not the best of solutions for folks with a stroke or other hand use issues. You have to put the book down on a table every time you want to turn a page.","Good, but convenience of use is an issue for me.";;;;;;

Review: Hardware: The dimension is just right and it is really light. The non-reflective screen surface ensures that this device can be used under various light conditions.Software: It has minimal features and thus is really good for users who are easily distracted by apps etc. The sole reading function makes this reader a must-have!

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"This is my third Kindle. My first was a Kindle with a keyboard. It was fairly light, but somewhat of a hassle to enter information. The keyboard letters have worn off which makes it even more difficult to use. I got a Fire, but did not like it as well because it was heavier and the charge port is sensitive and it is very difficult to get the cord in just right to have it charge.This Kindle is much lighter and has the touchscreen.  I have only had it for a couple of weeks. I really like it. It is lighter and smaller than my others.However, there are a few things I don't like. It did not come with any instructions. I am not having many problems with this since I owned other Kindles, but it could be a problem for a first time buyer.Also, the touch needed to turn a page is very light and sometimes more than one page is turned. I haven't gone into settings to see if I can adjust this yet, so maybe it is not a real problem.I would recommend this Kindle.",My favorite Kindle;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I am so much in love with this kindle way more than I thought I would ever be! Just was planning on using this as a transition to a tablet but now realizing that I won't be buying one at all! Kindles glare proof, easy to read, easy to use layout. And this kindle made me fall back in love with reading again!",Can I be the new kindle spokesperson?;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I usually read my books on my Windows Tablet or my Nook.  But, hated the glare when I'm at the beach.  So, when Amazon had their crazy sale in the summer for PRIME members, I got this Kindle for $49 to have just for the beach.  It is PERFECT for the beach!  It weighs about 1 lb, if that. And it fits perfectly in a quart ziploc bag (to keep out sand). I download all of my content from my tablet and I'm good to go!  My beach vacation was awesome.  I don't really use this on a day to day basis, as I prefer the tablet, but I do take it with me to my hair or Dr appointments that I know are going to be awhile.  Probably will take with me on my plane ride in January.  Just so light an portable!  Will fit in my purse.NOTE:  This doesn't have a backlight!  Can't read at night without a light.  Just think of it as a paperback, without the paper!Recommend for certain applications!",hated the glare when I'm at the beach;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"Love the new touch screen! It's lightweight, easy to use and small enough to put in my purse and take with me! The screen is great, I get headaches starring at a computer or phone screen for too long and this screen doesn't do that to me! I can read for hours and hours!",Love the new touchscreen!;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I am a first time kindle buyer. I've wanted one for quite sometime and after using the app on my phone for years I finally decided to purchase this one.I enjoy the touchscreen and don't understand how so many people have a problem with it. It's not that hard to not touch the screen while you're reading. I also like the size and feel of it in my hands. I actually like how the back is ridged because I find that it gives a better grip than something with smooth, rounded corners. One thing that I thought would be a problem after reading reviews was the text. Many people said it was pixelated and I began to worry that it would be a waste. While I don't know the quality of other kindles I find the text of this one to be good and easy to read.My one and only complaint is it's not backlit. I did order a reading light though so hopefully that will fix the issue.",I enjoy the touchscreen and don't understand how so many people ...;;;;;;

Review: I love it! I really liked the page turn buttons on my Kindle Classic and worried I wouldn't like touching the screen as much but the transition has been painless. The menu is intuitive and easy to navigate. Great upgrade!
Title;;;;;;: I love it! I really liked the page turn buttons ...;;;;;;

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"I love it! I got this as a promotion on Amazon where they let me split up my payments and Im so glad I took the offer!Im able to connect it on wifi and also i can use it with my Overdrive app and download library books to the device. The only downside to this is that it dont have a light but I ended up getting a light from Amazon that clips on it. I still would much prefer a lighted on, but I couldnt afford it and Im glad to be able to get me a glare free device. I would recommend this for vacations and long trips if you are a book lover",Great for the beach;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I didn't like touch screen before but this one is so easy, just touch the screen with a gentle press of your finger and the page is turned. Better than the Kindle Fire I bought for my husband a couple of years ago. I also like that I can turn off and turn on theWi-Fi.","Kindle, 6"" Glare-Free Touchscreen Display, WiFi";;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"Nice device but not the model you want if you love audio books. This is a nice kindle,  fast with no delays, with the touch screen, but it has no voice nor any speakers so you cannot have it read to you (something I treasure in my other kindle) and it wont play audio books either.  This is probably one of the reasons the battery lasts so much longer than older versions (up to a month). The look and feel is very nice and not heavy at all.  It costs $25 to remove the ads on it if you'd like to do that .I took one star off for the shopping cart symbol always at the top of the screen-I really dislike this type of thing on any reader.  I am reading and do not want to be prompted to go shopping by my kindle.  Also there you will find a g for Good reads which seems odd to me even though I know it is owned by amazon but then so are many things like Audible for which there is no letter.  This one does have a dictionary and if you highlight sections it will translate them to your choice of many languages.  It has wifi so you can order a book and download it in seconds while you are sitting in a Starbucks or anywhere else there is free working wifi.  I find it much easier to hold and read in a case and that is the solution to not turning pages accidentally much.","Audio Book lovers should not buy this model as there is no voice, no sound nor speakers!";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I love love love my basic kindle. I bought a kindle fire a couple years back because i live in a city and take the train to work every day and was tired of lugging around books to read, but i quickly discovered the kindle fire was just a bit too heavy in my purse and holding and it needed to be charged more often than i would have liked. So i got just a basic kindle and its wonderful. It weighs practically nothing so I can just throw it in my purse wherever I'm going. It's nice to have multiple books with me and it downloads ebooks quick and easily. The battery life last forever I can go a week or more without charging it. If you're a book worm who travels I highly recommend it.",I couldn't live without my kindle;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"My Kindle came before it the date given which was an added bonus. After tinkering with it for a bit, I have come to love it. It was easy to obtain the books from the Cloud and store onto the device. It also has a super simple user interface, which is what I was looking for. This does not have a back light, which I was aware upon purchase, but thought that it should be stated. The dictionary and highlighting options work well and I am rather impressed with them as well. The batter lasts for some time and as an avid reader, I find this to be extremely helpful. I like to read several books at once and have plenty of options, so if you are the same and travel a lot, this is something that is wonderful. I will update my review after a few more months to see if it stands the test of time. I expect the battery life to go down a bit, as all electronics, but so far I am impressed with this Kindle.",Great Product;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I used to read books on my phone, and I was really missing out. Reading on a kindle is a completely different experience, and I love it. The screen is a great size, and perfectly light to hold with one hand. The touch controls are responsive. Settings are simple and everything is fuss-free. This is much closer to how one might read an actual book - without the interruption of text message and email alerts, on pages that look so much like ink and paper. And the battery lasts for weeks!",I love my kindle!;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I bought my first kindle touch 5 years ago. After it stopped working I decided to get a new one. The newest model of the kindle touch looks great. I will go over the pros and cons of this kindle, and wether it is right for you. Pros: The kindle store gives special prices to kindle owners.(books are cheaper since they are e-books). Yesterday I got 3 books that would cost me about 70 in total for 15 bucks. This kindle's battery is great. With average use, about 2-3 hours of reading per day, this kindle should last about 5 days to a whole week. Its touch! Amazon got rid of the home button making this kindle completely touch. The touch is a bit more accurate than the older versions, and in my opinion, does not have to refresh as much as much.(when the screen turns black for a second). This pro is more like the first one which concerns all kindle users; The classics like
Review: hamlet and such are completely free. I had to get one of the classics for a class
Title;;;;;;: which cost $20 for the paperback. Its completely free in the kindle store! You can get this kindle for a reduced price if you choose to have special offers included. This just means there will be book ads
column4: which are not at all obtrusive
column5: and might even help you find a great new book to read. If you I do not know what a word means
column6: I can just tap and hold the word and a definition will pop up. This is great for reading hard books like the scarlet letter. Cons: Screen is delicate;" a case is a must for this kindle. The screen is glare free
column7: but if the light is right over you
column8: like in a room it will be impossible to read without changing position. The display's resolution is not that high
column9: and if u focus on the letters you can see the pixels
column10: which I don't mind that much
column11: but its still a con I guess. I do not like that the battery is not removable since it will hold less charge as time passes. I really like this kindle
column12: but the fact that you can't without light is sometimes annoying. I did not write this as a con because there is a kindle with built in lights
column13: but its more expensive.""
column14: A great product for a great price.";;;;

Review: I did not realize that there is no light to it.  I still find it hard to read it outside in bright sunshine but it makes a great back up for when I need to wait for doctor appointments.  It fits better in my purse than my larger kindle.
Title;;;;;;: I still find it hard to read it outside in bright sunshine but it makes a great back up for when I need to wait for ...;;;;;;

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"I had an older model Kindle that my son gave me for Christmas in 2011. While reading late one night, I dropped it and only about half the screen now works. I have quite a few unread books in the library and I continued reading one that I was about halfway through on my laptop computer. Though it is nice to be able to read the books on more than one device, a laptop is nowhere near as convenient as the Kindle so I decided to buy a new one.My old Kindle had a keyboard, but I never used it, so this model is working out fine for me. I wasn't sure how I would adjust to not having the little buttons on each side to flip pages, but I have very quickly adjusted to tapping the screen to move to the next page. (You should know that I am a dinosaur and do not use a smart phone, so I am not used to using a fingertip to change screens). Since this is a much newer model, on the home page there are pictures of the book cover rather than just titles listed like there were on the old model. They are in black and white, but at least a little more interesting than just a one line title and author.I pretty much use a computer to decide what titles I want, and to purchase them, and just use this device to actually read books. It's great for reading novels or non-fiction but I don't like it for reading textbooks. After 4 years of college and 7 years of graduate school, I need a real book with paper pages and a yellow highlighter to read textbooks. All in all, I am happy with the new model, no frills, Kindle.",Though it is nice to be able to read the books on more ...;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"Since so many of the reviews on this device are complaints about it not having a light function let me say THIS KINDLE DOES NOT HAVE A FRONTLIGHT.I would like to use this review to convince you NOT to buy the Paperwite or Voyage by comparing things that are important to me.Readability: I know that this model has almost half the PPI (167ppi) as the PW and Voyage  (300ppi) and this is a big selling point for Amazon but it honestly does not make that much of a difference when actually reading. Our brains do most of the work by recognizing symbols and shapes and filling things in so to speak that the text appears very crisp and very easy on the eyes with this device even with the lower ppi. Not a good reason to upgrade.Reading in the dark: The front light is such a gimmick. Not a good enough reason to upgrade IMHO since I can buy a darn good book light (you know, like we used back in the old days) for $4 vs an extra $40 for the PW that has the same functionality as this model (minus the light). I had the PW first gen and the light was really blotchy  and i personally noticed that my eyes strained when reading with that bluish white backlight for long periods at a time vs having the book light shining from above. This is just a personal preference, you'll have to decide for yourself which you prefer. I will say however that if your partner is very sensitive to light you might want to get the PW since you can turn the light down very low and squint to read that way.Design: All 3 kindle models are pretty basic looking tbh, not a good reason to upgrade. This model does NOT have the rubbery back that the PW has and is a very smooth plastic that makes it very slippery in the hands. I have found that both the PW and this Basic model are very easy to scratch and ruin the screen as my keys did when i put the PW in my purse. The good news however is that there are so many beautiful cheap cases on this site that remedy this. I purchased the Walnew Kindle 7th Gen Colorful Painting Smartshell Case - The Thinnest and Lightest Leather Cover for Amazon Kindle (With 6"" Glare-free Touchscreen and it does not add any bulk to the device and has a textured feeling making it easy to hold when reading. Cons: The Basic and PW both have the indented screen that is forever catching dust and crumbs in the corners and it drives me nuts and the voyage is the only model that has the smooth front. I refuse to pay $199 for a dedicated ereader though.Battery life: Same on all 3 IF you go easy on the light with the PW and Voyage. Hasn't been an issue. I should mention that none of the devices come with a wall plug but in this day and age honestly most people probably step on these regularly around the house. I certainly don't need another.This basic model is the definition of ""good enough"" for its purpose as a dedicated ereader. And since I'm mildly irritated at the rate Amazon is cranking out these ""upgraded"" kindles I have made a list of things I consider worthy of an upgrade. (BTW, If your thinking about buying an older version of the Kindle IT IS STILL SUPPORTED and you can still buy ebooks to send to the device).The only reason I'll ever upgrade:1. If Amazon FINALLY makes a waterproof Kindle for reading in the tub or on the beach. I have spilled tea on my Basic Kindle before and since there is not that many entrances (like a headphone jack or something) it survived just fine. I'd feel more secure about reading in the tub if I knew it was tested as waterproof though.2. If Amazon brings back the headphone jack for listening to audiobooks. I think they will probably have to make the storage expandable or offer more GBs if they do this since I think audio would take up more space than text. If this a concern for you the Kindle Keyboard (3rd gen) DOES have the headphone jack and i'm certain you can find a used one around going strong.Also Amazon seriously needs to get on the ball with the typography. Also very annoyed that EPUB is still not supported (you can convert ebooks with Calibre, but its a hassle) and that I am only allowed to lend books ONCE for like two weeks.",I would like to use this review to convince you NOT to ...;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I've always been a ""physical book"" type of of person, so I really wasn't sure if I would enjoy the kindle. However, I bought it for myself (and my mother) because it was on black Friday sale. Surprisingly, I absolutely love it! I'm currently reading the Outlander series by Diana Gabaldon (for those who don't know, the books average around 1000 pages, even going up to about 1500 pages), and it has made reading so much easier! I'm a graduate student, so I like to steal time for reading for pleasure when I can, and trying to manipulate a 1400 page book while eating a sandwich is really hard! :) The kindle is easier to hold (no flipping of pages or trying to get the book to stay open), and is really easy on the eyes. I find that my eyesight (previously better than 20/20) has worsened since spending so much time in front of a computer (thanks grad school :/), but this screen is designed for prolonged periods of reading. I really couldn't recommend it more! (although I will still continue to fill my bookshelves!)",so I really wasn't sure if I would enjoy the kindle;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"Having been a long-time user of the original Kindle, which itself was a 5-star product without a doubt, this later model is even lighter in weight and simpler to use, while providing the user with the same screen size and glare-free features.  Congratulations to Amazon on the ideal product for travelers and overseas residents who find it difficult to get printed books, and for those who prefer digital reading wherever they may be.","Simpler, lighter and even better than the original Kindle reader.";;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I was ""upgrading"" from an original Kindle that I've had for years.  I was nervous about the touch screen;" would it be responsive like my """"click"""" original one?  I was worried about the extras being accessible such as the type size
Review: home screen
column4: etc.  However
column5: all my fears proved to be nothing to worry about. This little Kindle is just great.  Just as easy to figure out and use. I love it! It is a great low-cost reader!~  I still love the Non-backlit option because I am more old-school as far as I want it to be more book-like.  I don't read my books on my tablet..I save them for the Kindle.""
column6: Nice reader for a low investment";;;;;

Rating: 4.0 out of 5 stars,"Bought this primarily to have a non backlit device for reading before bed time as studies show that ambient lighting results in greater restfulness during sleep, similar to a book. This Kindle is this in bright light and low light situations, especially at the beach. The native browser was a surprise, now I have to resist the temptation to check my email while off the clock and on holiday. Pretty amazing battery life overall, even with the WiFi on. Screen refresh is a bit slow and annotating is clunky but given that a change goes for a couple of weeks, I am not complaining.",The  Browser was a surprise;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"I do love this kindle. I bought it after I dropped my last Kindle in the hot tub (it will not survive, don't do it!) I think it was a 3rd generation, so this is an upgrade, I like most of the new features, although I was really excited to have the ""X-ray"" feature reading Game of Thrones, and it's not available for all books (and not GOT). I do wish there were more options for non-touchscreen so I could more easily use it in the hot tub more responsibly--I'll have to find one of those electronic cases with clear spot for touch screens on the front. This one weighs a little bit more than my old one, but it feels substantial. The only issue I've had is when trying to find some plastic that would let the touchscreen still work through it, the plastic not only didn't work, it messed with the touchscreen and freaked it out a few times, but since I quit trying, it's been fine. It's also a little bit harder to highlight, but with all the new features, it was just hard to find, and I know I just need to get used to how to use it. Overall, this a great basic eReader, definitely recommended, and a very good value for the price.",I do love my Kindle;;;;;;

Review: The Kindle is a worthwhile investment for me as it will help to remove the myriad paperbacks that I own. The only issue that I found was accidentally ending up on prime ( had to shut it off).  Actually the Kindle was a bit of a stretch for me since I am a paper book person.  I do like the cheaper prices for books though and being able to enlarge the print for those most of the day reading sessions.

Rating: 4.0 out of 5 stars,"I was pleasantly surprised with this Kindle. I've never had an e-Reader before, so I wasn't really sure what it expect. It was really on sale (Cyber Monday) on Amazon so I went ahead and ordered it to try it out.It seems pretty fast and works well. The user interface is a bit quirky, but I got used to it quickly. I wish it had text-to-speech capability to read books to me when I'm unable to look at it, but I can live without it.The screen is a little bit harder to see than paper, but not too bad. Sometimes the background seems to have a bit of a yellow tinge to it, which is odd and sometimes distracting, but not terrible.Battery life seems great. So far I've been reading it for many hours (8-10?) and it's still got more than half charge.It's very light and even fits in my back pocket! I wouldn't recommend sitting down with it there, though.I'd say it's definitely an improvement over paperbacks and hardcovers!",Pleasantly surprised;;;;;;

Review: After 3 plus years of constant use my first Kindle died.  This was the closest replacement model.  I wanted one that did not have a backlit screen and one that I could use outside.  I have a kindle fire and that which is impossible outside on a sunny day.  This Kindle has many features the other didn't have at the same price.  But if you are reading a book and want to get home you have to make sure you touch the screen in the exactly the right way and in the right place or you get stuck the dictionary or font size or highlight or whatever.  Also pages will jump just by jiggling the kindle.  The touch screen on the Kindle and Kindle Fire work differently.  You can drive yourself nuts switching between them.
Title;;;;;;: I loved my old Kindle.  I just like this one.;;;;;;

Review: Books bought at amazon look pretty good. PDF files are legible but it doesn't automatically resize to the proper screen size in order to display the text better. Fortunately one can pinch out to zoom in.
Title;;;;;;: Books bought at amazon look pretty good. PDF files are legible but it doesn't ...;;;;;;

Rating: 1.0 out of 5 stars,"I replaced my four year old basic (and quite dead) Kindle with this newer model.  It is sub-par.  It lags more, even with the same connection, and is of a cheaper quality.  There are no connections for a lighted case, and I am very angry about it.  This thing is dollar store quality, unlike the one it replaced, and if Amazon thinks this is a strategic ploy to get me to spend more money on a 'fancier' one...well that's an epic fail.  I'll be returning this piece of crap and switching to Nook.  I am so disgusted because I've been a diehard Kindle user since turning to the dark side of e-reading.You failed, Amazon.","Cheap, dollar store product.";;;;;;

Review: Just got my kindle yesterday and I LOVE it!!! I have tried to read on my kindle fire(s) but the weight was prohibitive due to my bad hand arthritis...I love the screen - very easy on the eyes. I am so excited to be able to read my favorite books and not be in pain. This is awesome and I wish I had bought it sooner!

Rating: 4.0 out of 5 stars,"The good:The matte screen is easier to read than a smart phone, so it's good for reading in long stretches. The touch sensitivity is good. The Kindle feels sturdy. The weight of it feels fine. The battery life is fine: I don't have to worry about it dying.The bad:I wish its case was not as slippery. I keep it in a cover, so it's not a big deal for me.It seems book collections made on it can't be imported to Kindle for PC, which makes it less useful. Making collections on the Kindle isn't fun.The experimental browser doesn't work as well as I want. It hung loading a site. I have read that mobile sites work better.The user interface could be better: A dialog box asking if I wanted something should have buttons saying yes or no, not OK and Cancel. But the UI is usable and it's out of the way when reading a book.Overall it's good for people who like to read a lot.",Pretty good;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"This was a great purchase.  I had a kindle 2nd generation that I was very happy with.  I was reluctant to upgrade over concerns some of the reviewers stated regarding the touch screen sensitivity and clarity.  I was also concerned about registration and not having access to previous books I had purchased.  I also had concerns about charging the battery with the adapter I had for the kindle 2.  Anyway, after a couple of months of consideration and a little more research, my wife convinced me I should buy the new kindle (birthday present), and I am very happy I did.  It works great.  All of my concerns were unfounded.  First of all it is much lighter and smaller than the kindle 2 (without sacrificing screen size).  It is easy to navigate using the touch screen and the drop down menus.  Registration was seamless, previous titles are readily available on the amazon cloud, and the battery charger adapter works fine.  Great product for those who love to read.  Highly recommended!",Great!;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I bought two of these just in time to take with me on a three-week vacation. Since I am now a published author with a book available for Kindle as well as a print edition, I thought I should get one of these. I've been wanting one for a long time, this particular model in fact. I have loaded all my manuscripts onto the Kindle and was able to review them and write notes. The experimental browser is, well, experimental I guess. I didn't buy the Kindle for the browser, so I'm glad that it had one at all. I was able to access Facebook, my bank's website, and other sites reasonably well. The Kindle introduced me to GoodReads, and I now have my author page set up there so people can follow me and review my book.",Exactly what I wanted.;;;;;;

5.0 out of 5 stars,"I like the idea of not having buttons on the sides of this device. I always used to hit them accidentally on other models. The display is perfectly clear and high contrast enough to read in any light where you can see well enough to walk around. Small and light, it's perfect for reading books. The only reason I could see wanting a different model is if you wanted a cellular connection for downloading books where there is no wifi.","Simple, Reliable, Inexpensive.";;;;;;

Review: Worst service I have ever received from Amazon and it will now determine if I ever buy a kindle again. The dedicated e reader kindle is shown as a paperwhite unless you read the very fine print that shows the $79  one is not actually a paperwhite it is just a regular kindle with touch screen. The advertising is completely misleading here and I was on the phone with amazon for over 40mins and all they wanted to do was sell me the new $200 kindle  or sell me a refurbished kindle for $99 both being the paperwhites?????? I was then transferred over to a supervisor who then started all over again to sell me a $200 kindle??????????????????????????????  very very very poor customer service
Title;;;;;;: kindle paperwhites are all not the same;;;;;;

Rating: 5.0 out of 5 stars,"This review is for the 7th Generation Kindle, which is now touch-screen only and has no buttons except for the lock/power button. All typing has been transferred to an in-screen keyboard popup. I love mine but some people really like their old kindle with the QWERTY keyboard buttons at the bottom. In nay case, the kindle is a great investment for book-worms with its multitude of features and has potential for web-browsing (on occasion), especially if Amazon improves on the experimental browser in the future (see review below).**** READABILITY & TEXT SCALING ****Kindle's e-ink technology re-creates an experience similar to reading a paperback book. I liken it to looking at an expensive etch-a-sketch. Text is crisp and easily readable. Contrast excellent. Despite its screen size (3 '' W x 4.75'' H or  9cm x 12 cm), you can scale text from the very smallest all the way up to the very largest. Like a book, reading in daylight or sun, is not a problem (but you may need sunglasses, obviously). At night, you'll need a light source to read.**** SEND CONTENT TO KINDLE. FROM ANYWHERE. AMAZON CLOUD ****Kindle servers will convert your content for the kindle for free. Works with most file formats -- even the text will be scalable. PDFs, however, are not scalable (and treated like an image). All content you send to yourself will be stored on the AmazonCloud drive (5GB of free storage). Be sure to read up on this cool feature--- I love it-- a definite plus for me: http://www.amazon.com/sendtokindle/**** LIBRARIES AND EBOOKS ****Many libraries in the US now allow you to access digital content (not just ebooks) and check them out while at home. No visit to the library required. I did this for the first time last week. I checked out two ebooks. Process was easy and ebooks delivered to my kindle in under a minute. If an ebook is checked out, I can put a hold on it (and, optionally, have it delivered to my kindle once it is available). Amazon will email you if a book becomes free, or when a book is due. Be sure you learn how to return a book (hint: deleting will be required).**** HIGHLIGHTS & ANNOTATIONS ****Kindle has incorporated ways to highlight and annotate passages using your finger. The best part is that all your markings and text will be uploaded to the cloud when you sync your kindle (along with page location of the book). Access and manage them here at anytime -- this is a really cool feature when writing yourself notes to look-up things later: https://kindle.amazon.com/your_highlights**** DICTIONARY / WORDWISE ****Keep learning words you don't know. Select an unfamiliar word and kindle will look it up for you using a standard dictionary and/or wikipedia (with a WiFi connection). Kindle can even keep track of words you've looked up. Test yourself using the the flashcards feature. WordWise is a predictive dictionary feature (available in some books) to suggest alternate meanings for complicated words (in between lines of text, pre-empting a dictionary search). Respected language dictionaries are available for English and most languages (for free!).**** COLLECTIONS ****""Collections"" allow you to sort books into your kindle and sync across multiple devices, instead of paging through multiple screens of all your content. Two important things to know before doing so:* collections are not file folders--merely tags-- but it will appear as if your books are in a folder on the kindle (but they actually are not)* collections created using kindle software apps on PC or Mac will not sync to your actual kindle. (Spare yourself my initial frustration and sort books into collections using only the a kindle or ipad. Trust me, I called Amazon upset because my collections wouldn't sync and update to the kindle from my computer. Apparently, the sync-ing of collections was disabled a while but there is no documentation of this anywhere)DRAWBACKS**** Experimental Browser ****I like this feature, but it is buggy. You can use the ""experimental browser"" to surf the web, amazon.com, check email (limited). It will frequently crash, especially with flash content (which it does not support). Amazon.com is fine, however (so you can buy more ebooks). The frustrating part is that when the browser crashes,it re-loads your last visited page... a catch-22 because it loads the page causing it to crash in the first place.* you'll need nimble fingers to hit the back button or the stop loading (x) button in the address bar to resolve the crashing**** Lighting ****It needs a light when it gets dark... but that is because it's supposed to be like a book. Solution: kindle cover/case with in-built or clip-on light.**** Screen Bursts/Reloads ****Eventually, you will get used to that split-second screen burst when the e-ink re-sets itself. This is frequent, but not always, it just depends on the e-ink formatting needs from screen to screen. (Remember, the kindle is like a souped up etch-a-sketch)**** ADDITIONAL TIPS AND RECOMMENDATIONS ********************** BOOKMARK YOUR BROWSER *****Highlights & Annotations: https://kindle.amazon.com/your_highlightsManage Content & Settings: https://www.amazon.com/mn/dcw/myx.htmlAmazonCloud Drive: https://www.amazon.com/clouddrive/**** WiFi vs. Whispernet ****Be sure you learn the difference between sending content to yourself for free (via a WiFi connection) or Whispernet (not free, charges apply--I haven't used this feature so far).**** Kindle Case/Cover ****Protect your investment with a kindle case or cover. I could imagine the screen getting scratched or marked by objects in a backpack, purse, or murse. My $10 case should get here in a couple of days.",Some people really like their old kindle with the QWERTY keyboard;;;;;;

4.0 out of 5 stars,"First of all I should say that I do love my kindle. This is my third, before which I had a nook. And to date I think this is the best. I prefer this stripped down version to the fancier ones, because just as with a car, the more gadgets and added features there are, the more parts there are that may break. I would rather just read with the light on in the room than rely on a reader to light up for me. I am an advance reader, and I go through two or three books weekly. (The promise of a week of battery power is ridiculous, because it doesn't take into account how much reading one does in a given day.)Those of us with arthritis have been assisted tremendously by the kindle. Sometimes I select very lengthy works that would be huge if I had to handle the physical book. And because of arthritic issues I prefer this version of the basic kindle to the one I just wore out. Not having the buttons down the side, but relying on a touch screen instead, is far easier on the thumbs. And highlighting by touch is far easier on the hands than having to navigate to each individual letter, one click at a time. This version makes it far easier to access footnotes and the dictionary. But there are some kinks that still need to be worked out.I use the features constantly, since I am almost always reading a book with the intent of reviewing it. The touch screen needs improvement. Trying to highlight too far left or too far right sometimes causes the page to turn unexpectedly. Trying to highlight in the topmost 20% causes the tool bar to pop up. It is possible to highlight these areas, but one has to touch it exactly straight on and hold for a moment, and frankly it's a pain in the butt. In addition, the keyboard has a terrible auto correct bar. I have an Android phone that can guess what I want to type very early, but this one has no clue. When using the secondary keyboard for punctuation, the next word after the space bar is tapped should pop up as the main keyboard with letters but it doesn't; we must move it back manually every stinking time. And try the bookmark! One cannot just tap the upper right corner
Review: because that will either bring up the tool bar or cause a letter nearby to be highlighted. The only way to use the bookmark
column4: is by first bringing up the tool bar
column5: then selecting bookmark
column6: then tapping a third time to verify that one wants to place a book mark in the corner.For those that don't often use the features and just want to read the book and have the kindle remember your place
column7: it's a pretty good reader. The text is clear
column8: and the font size is easy to change without causing the paragraphs to go out of alignment.The insidious suggestion that we link our Goodreads account to our Amazon account is the worst potential invasion of privacy I can imagine. I began my to-read list
column9: which has hundreds of titles
column10: with the casual intent to read those books if I ran across them;" it was never meant to be a wish list. Of course
column11: all I had to do there is ignore the prominent invitation to link my two accounts
column12: but it's worth noting.All told
